### `atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_options.create_custom_field_option`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_custom_field_optionscreate_custom_field_option"></a>

Creates options and, where the custom select field is of the type Select List (cascading), cascading options for a custom select field. The options are added to a context of the field.

The maximum number of options that can be created per request is 1000 and each field can have a maximum of 10000 options.

This operation works for custom field options created in Jira or the operations from this resource. **To work with issue field select list options created for Connect apps use the [Issue custom field options (apps)](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) operations.**

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
create_custom_field_option_response = atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_options.create_custom_field_option(
    field_id="fieldId_example",
    context_id=1,
    options=[
        {
            "value": "value_example",
        }
    ],
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

The ID of the custom field.

##### context_id: `int`<a id="context_id-int"></a>

The ID of the context.

##### options: List[`CustomFieldOptionCreate`]<a id="options-listcustomfieldoptioncreate"></a>

Details of options to create.

[`BulkCustomFieldOptionCreateRequest`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/bulk_custom_field_option_create_request.py)

[`CustomFieldCreatedContextOptionsList`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/custom_field_created_context_options_list.py)

### `atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_options_(apps).create_field_option`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_custom_field_options_appscreate_field_option"></a>

Creates an option for a select list issue field.

Note that this operation **only works for issue field select list options added by Connect apps**, it cannot be used with issue field select list options created in Jira or using operations from the [Issue custom field options](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource.

Each field can have a maximum of 10000 options, and each option can have a maximum of 10000 scopes.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg). Jira permissions are not required for the app providing the field.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
create_field_option_response = atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_options_(apps).create_field_option(
    value="string_example",
    field_key="fieldKey_example",
    config={
    },
    properties={
        "key": None,
    },
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### value: `str`<a id="value-str"></a>

The option's name, which is displayed in Jira.

##### field_key: `str`<a id="field_key-str"></a>

The field key is specified in the following format: **$(app-key)\\_\\_$(field-key)**. For example, *example-add-on\\_\\_example-issue-field*. To determine the `fieldKey` value, do one of the following:   *  open the app's plugin descriptor, then **app-key** is the key at the top and **field-key** is the key in the `jiraIssueFields` module. **app-key** can also be found in the app listing in the Atlassian Universal Plugin Manager.  *  run [Get fields](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and in the field details the value is returned in `key`. For example, `\"key\": \"teams-add-on__team-issue-field\"`

##### config: [`IssueFieldOptionConfiguration`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_field_option_configuration.py)<a id="config-issuefieldoptionconfigurationatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeissue_field_option_configurationpy"></a>


##### properties: [`IssueFieldOptionCreateBeanProperties`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_field_option_create_bean_properties.py)<a id="properties-issuefieldoptioncreatebeanpropertiesatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeissue_field_option_create_bean_propertiespy"></a>

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`IssueFieldOptionCreateBean`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_field_option_create_bean.py)
#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`IssueFieldOption`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/issue_field_option.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/field/{fieldKey}/option` `post`

### `atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_options_(apps).deselect_option_from_issues`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_custom_field_options_appsdeselect_option_from_issues"></a>

Deselects an issue-field select-list option from all issues where it is selected. A different option can be selected to replace the deselected option. The update can also be limited to a smaller set of issues by using a JQL query.

Connect and Forge app users with *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg) can override the screen security configuration using `overrideScreenSecurity` and `overrideEditableFlag`.

This is an [asynchronous operation](https://dac-static.atlassian.com). The response object contains a link to the long-running task.

Note that this operation **only works for issue field select list options added by Connect apps**, it cannot be used with issue field select list options created in Jira or using operations from the [Issue custom field options](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg). Jira permissions are not required for the app providing the field.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_options_(apps).deselect_option_from_issues(
    field_key="fieldKey_example",
    option_id=1,
    replace_with=1,
    jql="string_example",
    override_screen_security=False,
    override_editable_flag=False,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### field_key: `str`<a id="field_key-str"></a>

The field key is specified in the following format: **$(app-key)\\_\\_$(field-key)**. For example, *example-add-on\\_\\_example-issue-field*. To determine the `fieldKey` value, do one of the following:   *  open the app's plugin descriptor, then **app-key** is the key at the top and **field-key** is the key in the `jiraIssueFields` module. **app-key** can also be found in the app listing in the Atlassian Universal Plugin Manager.  *  run [Get fields](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and in the field details the value is returned in `key`. For example, `\"key\": \"teams-add-on__team-issue-field\"`

##### option_id: `int`<a id="option_id-int"></a>

The ID of the option to be deselected.

##### replace_with: `int`<a id="replace_with-int"></a>

The ID of the option that will replace the currently selected option.

##### jql: `str`<a id="jql-str"></a>

A JQL query that specifies the issues to be updated. For example, *project=10000*.

##### override_screen_security: `bool`<a id="override_screen_security-bool"></a>

Whether screen security is overridden to enable hidden fields to be edited. Available to Connect and Forge app users with admin permission.

##### override_editable_flag: `bool`<a id="override_editable_flag-bool"></a>

Whether screen security is overridden to enable uneditable fields to be edited. Available to Connect and Forge app users with *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/field/{fieldKey}/option/{optionId}/issue` `delete`

### `atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_options_(apps).get_selectable_issue_field_options`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_custom_field_options_appsget_selectable_issue_field_options"></a>

Returns a [paginated](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) list of options for a select list issue field that can be viewed and selected by the user.

Note that this operation **only works for issue field select list options added by Connect apps**, it cannot be used with issue field select list options created in Jira or using operations from the [Issue custom field options](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Permission to access Jira.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_selectable_issue_field_options_response = atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_options_(apps).get_selectable_issue_field_options(
    field_key="fieldKey_example",
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
    project_id=1,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### field_key: `str`<a id="field_key-str"></a>

The field key is specified in the following format: **$(app-key)\\_\\_$(field-key)**. For example, *example-add-on\\_\\_example-issue-field*. To determine the `fieldKey` value, do one of the following:   *  open the app's plugin descriptor, then **app-key** is the key at the top and **field-key** is the key in the `jiraIssueFields` module. **app-key** can also be found in the app listing in the Atlassian Universal Plugin Manager.  *  run [Get fields](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and in the field details the value is returned in `key`. For example, `\"key\": \"teams-add-on__team-issue-field\"`

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### project_id: `int`<a id="project_id-int"></a>

Filters the results to options that are only available in the specified project.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`PageBeanIssueFieldOption`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/page_bean_issue_field_option.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/field/{fieldKey}/option/suggestions/edit` `get`

### `atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_options_(apps).update_option_by_id`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_custom_field_options_appsupdate_option_by_id"></a>

Updates or creates an option for a select list issue field. This operation requires that the option ID is provided when creating an option, therefore, the option ID needs to be specified as a path and body parameter. The option ID provided in the path and body must be identical.

Note that this operation **only works for issue field select list options added by Connect apps**, it cannot be used with issue field select list options created in Jira or using operations from the [Issue custom field options](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg). Jira permissions are not required for the app providing the field.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
update_option_by_id_response = atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_options_(apps).update_option_by_id(
    id=1,
    value="string_example",
    field_key="fieldKey_example",
    option_id=1,
    config={
    },
    properties={
        "key": None,
    },
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### id: `int`<a id="id-int"></a>

The unique identifier for the option. This is only unique within the select field's set of options.

##### value: `str`<a id="value-str"></a>

The option's name, which is displayed in Jira.

##### field_key: `str`<a id="field_key-str"></a>

The field key is specified in the following format: **$(app-key)\\_\\_$(field-key)**. For example, *example-add-on\\_\\_example-issue-field*. To determine the `fieldKey` value, do one of the following:   *  open the app's plugin descriptor, then **app-key** is the key at the top and **field-key** is the key in the `jiraIssueFields` module. **app-key** can also be found in the app listing in the Atlassian Universal Plugin Manager.  *  run [Get fields](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and in the field details the value is returned in `key`. For example, `\"key\": \"teams-add-on__team-issue-field\"`

##### option_id: `int`<a id="option_id-int"></a>

The ID of the option to be updated.

##### config: [`IssueFieldOptionConfiguration`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_field_option_configuration.py)<a id="config-issuefieldoptionconfigurationatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeissue_field_option_configurationpy"></a>


##### properties: [`IssueFieldOptionProperties`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_field_option_properties.py)<a id="properties-issuefieldoptionpropertiesatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeissue_field_option_propertiespy"></a>

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`IssueFieldOption`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_field_option.py)
#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`IssueFieldOption`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/issue_field_option.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/field/{fieldKey}/option/{optionId}` `put`

### `atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_values_(apps).update_value`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_custom_field_values_appsupdate_value"></a>

Updates the value of a custom field on one or more issues.

Apps can only perform this operation on [custom fields](https://developer.atlassian.com/platform/forge/manifest-reference/modules/jira-custom-field/) and [custom field types](https://developer.atlassian.com/platform/forge/manifest-reference/modules/jira-custom-field-type/) declared in their own manifests.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Only the app that owns the custom field or custom field type can update its values with this operation.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
update_value_response = atlassianjira.issue_custom_field_values_(apps).update_value(
    field_id_or_key="fieldIdOrKey_example",
    updates=[
        {
            "issue_ids": [
                1
            ],
            "value": None,
        }
    ],
    generate_changelog=True,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### field_id_or_key: `str`<a id="field_id_or_key-str"></a>

The ID or key of the custom field. For example, `customfield_10010`.

##### updates: List[`CustomFieldValueUpdate`]<a id="updates-listcustomfieldvalueupdate"></a>

The list of custom field update details.

##### generate_changelog: `bool`<a id="generate_changelog-bool"></a>

Whether to generate a changelog for this update.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`CustomFieldValueUpdateDetails`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/custom_field_value_update_details.py)
#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/app/field/{fieldIdOrKey}/value` `put`

### `atlassianjira.issue_field_configurations.get_all_field_configurations`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_field_configurationsget_all_field_configurations"></a>

Returns a [paginated](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) list of field configurations. The list can be for all field configurations or a subset determined by any combination of these criteria:

 *  a list of field configuration item IDs.
 *  whether the field configuration is a default.
 *  whether the field configuration name or description contains a query string.

Only field configurations used in company-managed (classic) projects are returned.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_all_field_configurations_response = atlassianjira.issue_field_configurations.get_all_field_configurations(
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
    id=[
        1
    ],
    is_default=False,
    query="",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### id: List[`int`]<a id="id-listint"></a>

The list of field configuration IDs. To include multiple IDs, provide an ampersand-separated list. For example, `id=10000&id=10001`.

##### is_default: `bool`<a id="is_default-bool"></a>

If *true* returns default field configurations only.

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

The query string used to match against field configuration names and descriptions.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`PageBeanFieldConfigurationDetails`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/page_bean_field_configuration_details.py)

Returns a [paginated](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) list of field configuration schemes and, for each scheme, a list of the projects that use it.

The list is sorted by field configuration scheme ID. The first item contains the list of project IDs assigned to the default field configuration scheme.

Only field configuration schemes used in classic projects are returned.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_field_configuration_schemes_for_projects_response = atlassianjira.issue_field_configurations.get_field_configuration_schemes_for_projects(
    project_id=[
        1
    ],
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
)
```

##### project_id: List[`int`]<a id="project_id-listint"></a>

The list of project IDs. To include multiple projects, separate IDs with ampersand: `projectId=10000&projectId=10001`.

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

```python
            "id": "id_example",
        }
    ],
    id=1,
)
```

### `atlassianjira.issue_fields.create_custom_field`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_fieldscreate_custom_field"></a>

Creates a custom field.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
create_custom_field_response = atlassianjira.issue_fields.create_custom_field(
    name="string_example",
    type="string_example",
    description="string_example",
    searcher_key="com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:cascadingselectsearcher",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### name: `str`<a id="name-str"></a>

The name of the custom field, which is displayed in Jira. This is not the unique identifier.

##### type: `str`<a id="type-str"></a>

The type of the custom field. These built-in custom field types are available:   *  `cascadingselect`: Enables values to be selected from two levels of select lists (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:cascadingselect`)  *  `datepicker`: Stores a date using a picker control (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:datepicker`)  *  `datetime`: Stores a date with a time component (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:datetime`)  *  `float`: Stores and validates a numeric (floating point) input (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:float`)  *  `grouppicker`: Stores a user group using a picker control (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:grouppicker`)  *  `importid`: A read-only field that stores the ID the issue had in the system it was imported from (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:importid`)  *  `labels`: Stores labels (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:labels`)  *  `multicheckboxes`: Stores multiple values using checkboxes (value: ``)  *  `multigrouppicker`: Stores multiple user groups using a picker control (value: ``)  *  `multiselect`: Stores multiple values using a select list (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:multicheckboxes`)  *  `multiuserpicker`: Stores multiple users using a picker control (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:multigrouppicker`)  *  `multiversion`: Stores multiple versions from the versions available in a project using a picker control (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:multiversion`)  *  `project`: Stores a project from a list of projects that the user is permitted to view (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:project`)  *  `radiobuttons`: Stores a value using radio buttons (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:radiobuttons`)  *  `readonlyfield`: Stores a read-only text value, which can only be populated via the API (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:readonlyfield`)  *  `select`: Stores a value from a configurable list of options (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:select`)  *  `textarea`: Stores a long text string using a multiline text area (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:textarea`)  *  `textfield`: Stores a text string using a single-line text box (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:textfield`)  *  `url`: Stores a URL (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:url`)  *  `userpicker`: Stores a user using a picker control (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:userpicker`)  *  `version`: Stores a version using a picker control (value: `com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:version`)  To create a field based on a [Forge custom field type](https://developer.atlassian.com/platform/forge/manifest-reference/modules/#jira-custom-field-type--beta-), use the ID of the Forge custom field type as the value. For example, `ari:cloud:ecosystem::extension/e62f20a2-4b61-4dbe-bfb9-9a88b5e3ac84/548c5df1-24aa-4f7c-bbbb-3038d947cb05/static/my-cf-type-key`.

##### description: `str`<a id="description-str"></a>

The description of the custom field, which is displayed in Jira.

##### searcher_key: `str`<a id="searcher_key-str"></a>

The searcher defines the way the field is searched in Jira. For example, *com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:grouppickersearcher*.   The search UI (basic search and JQL search) will display different operations and values for the field, based on the field searcher. You must specify a searcher that is valid for the field type, as listed below (abbreviated values shown):   *  `cascadingselect`: `cascadingselectsearcher`  *  `datepicker`: `daterange`  *  `datetime`: `datetimerange`  *  `float`: `exactnumber` or `numberrange`  *  `grouppicker`: `grouppickersearcher`  *  `importid`: `exactnumber` or `numberrange`  *  `labels`: `labelsearcher`  *  `multicheckboxes`: `multiselectsearcher`  *  `multigrouppicker`: `multiselectsearcher`  *  `multiselect`: `multiselectsearcher`  *  `multiuserpicker`: `userpickergroupsearcher`  *  `multiversion`: `versionsearcher`  *  `project`: `projectsearcher`  *  `radiobuttons`: `multiselectsearcher`  *  `readonlyfield`: `textsearcher`  *  `select`: `multiselectsearcher`  *  `textarea`: `textsearcher`  *  `textfield`: `textsearcher`  *  `url`: `exacttextsearcher`  *  `userpicker`: `userpickergroupsearcher`  *  `version`: `versionsearcher`  If no searcher is provided, the field isn't searchable. However, [Forge custom fields](https://developer.atlassian.com/platform/forge/manifest-reference/modules/#jira-custom-field-type--beta-) have a searcher set automatically, so are always searchable.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`CustomFieldDefinitionJsonBean`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/custom_field_definition_json_bean.py)
Definition of the custom field to be created

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`FieldDetails`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/field_details.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/field` `post`

### `atlassianjira.issue_fields.get_fields_paginated`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_fieldsget_fields_paginated"></a>

Returns a [paginated](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) list of fields for Classic Jira projects. The list can include:

 *  all fields
 *  specific fields, by defining `id`
 *  fields that contain a string in the field name or description, by defining `query`
 *  specific fields that contain a string in the field name or description, by defining `id` and `query`

Only custom fields can be queried, `type` must be set to `custom`.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_fields_paginated_response = atlassianjira.issue_fields.get_fields_paginated(
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
    type=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    id=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    query="string_example",
    order_by="contextsCount",
    expand="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### type: List[`str`]<a id="type-liststr"></a>

The type of fields to search.

##### id: List[`str`]<a id="id-liststr"></a>

The IDs of the custom fields to return or, where `query` is specified, filter.

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

String used to perform a case-insensitive partial match with field names or descriptions.

##### order_by: `str`<a id="order_by-str"></a>

[Order](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) the results by a field:   *  `contextsCount` sorts by the number of contexts related to a field  *  `lastUsed` sorts by the date when the value of the field last changed  *  `name` sorts by the field name  *  `screensCount` sorts by the number of screens related to a field

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use [expand](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to include additional information in the response. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Expand options include:   *  `key` returns the key for each field  *  `lastUsed` returns the date when the value of the field last changed  *  `screensCount` returns the number of screens related to a field  *  `contextsCount` returns the number of contexts related to a field  *  `isLocked` returns information about whether the field is [locked](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/ZSN7Og)  *  `searcherKey` returns the searcher key for each custom field

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`PageBeanField`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/page_bean_field.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/field/search` `get`

### `atlassianjira.issue_fields.get_system_and_custom_fields`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_fieldsget_system_and_custom_fields"></a>

Returns system and custom issue fields according to the following rules:

 *  Fields that cannot be added to the issue navigator are always returned.
 *  Fields that cannot be placed on an issue screen are always returned.
 *  Fields that depend on global Jira settings are only returned if the setting is enabled. That is, timetracking fields, subtasks, votes, and watches.
 *  For all other fields, this operation only returns the fields that the user has permission to view (that is, the field is used in at least one project that the user has *Browse Projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for.)

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** None.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_system_and_custom_fields_response = atlassianjira.issue_fields.get_system_and_custom_fields()
```

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`IssueFieldsGetSystemAndCustomFieldsResponse`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/issue_fields_get_system_and_custom_fields_response.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/field` `get`

### `atlassianjira.issue_link_types.create_link_type`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_link_typescreate_link_type"></a>

Creates an issue link type. Use this operation to create descriptions of the reasons why issues are linked. The issue link type consists of a name and descriptions for a link's inward and outward relationships.

To use this operation, the site must have [issue linking](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yoXKM) enabled.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
create_link_type_response = atlassianjira.issue_link_types.create_link_type(
    id="string_example",
    inward="string_example",
    name="string_example",
    outward="string_example",
    _self="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### id: `str`<a id="id-str"></a>

The ID of the issue link type and is used as follows:   *  In the [issueLink](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource it is the type of issue link. Required on create when `name` isn't provided. Otherwise, read only.  *  In the [issueLinkType](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource it is read only.

##### inward: `str`<a id="inward-str"></a>

The description of the issue link type inward link and is used as follows:   *  In the [issueLink](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource it is read only.  *  In the [issueLinkType](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource it is required on create and optional on update. Otherwise, read only.

##### name: `str`<a id="name-str"></a>

The name of the issue link type and is used as follows:   *  In the [issueLink](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource it is the type of issue link. Required on create when `id` isn't provided. Otherwise, read only.  *  In the [issueLinkType](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource it is required on create and optional on update. Otherwise, read only.

##### outward: `str`<a id="outward-str"></a>

The description of the issue link type outward link and is used as follows:   *  In the [issueLink](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource it is read only.  *  In the [issueLinkType](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource it is required on create and optional on update. Otherwise, read only.

##### _self: `str`<a id="_self-str"></a>

The URL of the issue link type. Read only.

### `atlassianjira.issue_links.create_link`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_linkscreate_link"></a>

Creates a link between two issues. Use this operation to indicate a relationship between two issues and optionally add a comment to the from (outward) issue. To use this resource the site must have [Issue Linking](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yoXKM) enabled.

This resource returns nothing on the creation of an issue link. To obtain the ID of the issue link, use `https://your-domain.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/issue/[linked issue key]?fields=issuelinks`.

If the link request duplicates a link, the response indicates that the issue link was created. If the request included a comment, the comment is added.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:**

 *  *Browse project* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for all the projects containing the issues to be linked,
 *  *Link issues* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) on the project containing the from (outward) issue,
 *  If [issue-level security](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/J4lKLg) is configured, issue-level security permission to view the issue.
 *  If the comment has visibility restrictions, belongs to the group or has the role visibility is restricted to.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
create_link_response = atlassianjira.issue_links.create_link(
    inward_issue={
    },
    outward_issue={
    },
    type={
    },
    comment={
    },
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### inward_issue: [`LinkedIssue`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/linked_issue.py)<a id="inward_issue-linkedissueatlassian_jira_python_sdktypelinked_issuepy"></a>


##### outward_issue: [`LinkedIssue`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/linked_issue.py)<a id="outward_issue-linkedissueatlassian_jira_python_sdktypelinked_issuepy"></a>


##### type: [`IssueLinkType`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_link_type.py)<a id="type-issuelinktypeatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeissue_link_typepy"></a>


##### comment: [`Comment`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/comment.py)<a id="comment-commentatlassian_jira_python_sdktypecommentpy"></a>


#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`LinkIssueRequestJsonBean`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/link_issue_request_json_bean.py)
The issue link request.

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/issueLink` `post`

### `atlassianjira.issue_navigator_settings.set_issue_navigator_default_columns`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_navigator_settingsset_issue_navigator_default_columns"></a>

Sets the default issue navigator columns.

The `columns` parameter accepts a navigable field value and is expressed as HTML form data. To specify multiple columns, pass multiple `columns` parameters. For example, in curl:

`curl -X PUT -d columns=summary -d columns=description https://your-domain.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/settings/columns`

If no column details are sent, then all default columns are removed.

A navigable field is one that can be used as a column on the issue navigator. Find details of navigable issue columns using [Get fields](https://dac-static.atlassian.com).

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
atlassianjira.issue_navigator_settings.set_issue_navigator_default_columns(
    columns=[
        "string_example"
    ],
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### columns: [`ColumnRequestBodyColumns`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/column_request_body_columns.py)<a id="columns-columnrequestbodycolumnsatlassian_jira_python_sdktypecolumn_request_body_columnspy"></a>

### `atlassianjira.issue_properties.bulk_delete_issue_property_by_filter`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_propertiesbulk_delete_issue_property_by_filter"></a>

Deletes a property value from multiple issues. The issues to be updated can be specified by filter criteria.

The criteria the filter used to identify eligible issues are:

 *  `entityIds` Only issues from this list are eligible.
 *  `currentValue` Only issues with the property set to this value are eligible.

If both criteria is specified, they are joined with the logical *AND*: only issues that satisfy both criteria are considered eligible.

If no filter criteria are specified, all the issues visible to the user and where the user has the EDIT\_ISSUES permission for the issue are considered eligible.

This operation is:

 *  transactional, either the property is deleted from all eligible issues or, when errors occur, no properties are deleted.
 *  [asynchronous](https://dac-static.atlassian.com). Follow the `location` link in the response to determine the status of the task and use [Get task](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to obtain subsequent updates.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:**

 *  *Browse projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for each project containing issues.
 *  If [issue-level security](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/J4lKLg) is configured, issue-level security permission to view the issue.
 *  *Edit issues* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for each issue.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
atlassianjira.issue_properties.bulk_delete_issue_property_by_filter(
    property_key="propertyKey_example",
    current_value=None,
    entity_ids=[
        1
    ],
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### property_key: `str`<a id="property_key-str"></a>

The key of the property.

##### current_value: [`Union[bool, date, datetime, dict, float, int, list, str, None]`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/typing_union_bool_date_datetime_dict_float_int_list_str_none.py)<a id="current_value-unionbool-date-datetime-dict-float-int-list-str-noneatlassian_jira_python_sdktypetyping_union_bool_date_datetime_dict_float_int_list_str_nonepy"></a>

The value of properties to perform the bulk operation on.

##### entity_ids: [`IssueFilterForBulkPropertyDeleteEntityIds`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_filter_for_bulk_property_delete_entity_ids.py)<a id="entity_ids-issuefilterforbulkpropertydeleteentityidsatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeissue_filter_for_bulk_property_delete_entity_idspy"></a>

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`IssueFilterForBulkPropertyDelete`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_filter_for_bulk_property_delete.py)
#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/issue/properties/{propertyKey}` `delete`

### `atlassianjira.issue_properties.bulk_set_issue_property_by_list`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_propertiesbulk_set_issue_property_by_list"></a>

Sets a property value on multiple issues.

The value set can be a constant or determined by a [Jira expression](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/jira-expressions/). Expressions must be computable with constant complexity when applied to a set of issues. Expressions must also comply with the [restrictions](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/jira-expressions/#restrictions) that apply to all Jira expressions.

The issues to be updated can be specified by a filter.

The filter identifies issues eligible for update using these criteria:

 *  `entityIds` Only issues from this list are eligible.
 *  `currentValue` Only issues with the property set to this value are eligible.
 *  `hasProperty`:
    
     *  If *true*, only issues with the property are eligible.
     *  If *false*, only issues without the property are eligible.

If more than one criteria is specified, they are joined with the logical *AND*: only issues that satisfy all criteria are eligible.

If an invalid combination of criteria is provided, an error is returned. For example, specifying a `currentValue` and `hasProperty` as *false* would not match any issues (because without the property the property cannot have a value).

The filter is optional. Without the filter all the issues visible to the user and where the user has the EDIT\_ISSUES permission for the issue are considered eligible.

This operation is:

 *  transactional, either all eligible issues are updated or, when errors occur, none are updated.
 *  [asynchronous](https://dac-static.atlassian.com). Follow the `location` link in the response to determine the status of the task and use [Get task](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to obtain subsequent updates.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:**

 *  *Browse projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for each project containing issues.
 *  If [issue-level security](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/J4lKLg) is configured, issue-level security permission to view the issue.
 *  *Edit issues* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for each issue.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
atlassianjira.issue_properties.bulk_set_issue_property_by_list(
    property_key="propertyKey_example",
    expression="string_example",
    filter={
    },
    value=None,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### property_key: `str`<a id="property_key-str"></a>

The key of the property. The maximum length is 255 characters.

##### expression: `str`<a id="expression-str"></a>

EXPERIMENTAL. The Jira expression to calculate the value of the property. The value of the expression must be an object that can be converted to JSON, such as a number, boolean, string, list, or map. The context variables available to the expression are `issue` and `user`. Issues for which the expression returns a value whose JSON representation is longer than 32768 characters are ignored.

##### filter: [`IssueFilterForBulkPropertySet`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_filter_for_bulk_property_set.py)<a id="filter-issuefilterforbulkpropertysetatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeissue_filter_for_bulk_property_setpy"></a>


The bulk operation filter.

##### value: [`Union[bool, date, datetime, dict, float, int, list, str, None]`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/typing_union_bool_date_datetime_dict_float_int_list_str_none.py)<a id="value-unionbool-date-datetime-dict-float-int-list-str-noneatlassian_jira_python_sdktypetyping_union_bool_date_datetime_dict_float_int_list_str_nonepy"></a>

The value of the property. The value must be a [valid](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4627), non-empty JSON blob. The maximum length is 32768 characters.

### `atlassianjira.issue_remote_links.create_or_update_remote_issue_link`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_remote_linkscreate_or_update_remote_issue_link"></a>

Creates or updates a remote issue link for an issue.

If a `globalId` is provided and a remote issue link with that global ID is found it is updated. Any fields without values in the request are set to null. Otherwise, the remote issue link is created.

This operation requires [issue linking to be active](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yoXKM).

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:**

 *  *Browse projects* and *Link issues* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project that the issue is in.
 *  If [issue-level security](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/J4lKLg) is configured, issue-level security permission to view the issue.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
create_or_update_remote_issue_link_response = atlassianjira.issue_remote_links.create_or_update_remote_issue_link(
    object={
        "title": "title_example",
        "url": "url_example",
    },
    issue_id_or_key="issueIdOrKey_example",
    application={
    },
    global_id="string_example",
    relationship="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### object: [`RemoteObject`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/remote_object.py)<a id="object-remoteobjectatlassian_jira_python_sdktyperemote_objectpy"></a>


##### issue_id_or_key: `str`<a id="issue_id_or_key-str"></a>

The ID or key of the issue.

##### application: [`Application`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/application.py)<a id="application-applicationatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeapplicationpy"></a>


##### global_id: `str`<a id="global_id-str"></a>

An identifier for the remote item in the remote system. For example, the global ID for a remote item in Confluence would consist of the app ID and page ID, like this: `appId=456&pageId=123`.  Setting this field enables the remote issue link details to be updated or deleted using remote system and item details as the record identifier, rather than using the record's Jira ID.  The maximum length is 255 characters.

##### relationship: `str`<a id="relationship-str"></a>

Description of the relationship between the issue and the linked item. If not set, the relationship description \\\"links to\\\" is used in Jira.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`RemoteIssueLinkRequest`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/remote_issue_link_request.py)
#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`RemoteIssueLinkIdentifies`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/remote_issue_link_identifies.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/issue/{issueIdOrKey}/remotelink` `post`

### `atlassianjira.issue_search.jql_get`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_searchjql_get"></a>

Searches for issues using [JQL](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/egORLQ).

If the JQL query expression is too large to be encoded as a query parameter, use the [POST](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) version of this resource.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Issues are included in the response where the user has:

 *  *Browse projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project containing the issue.
 *  If [issue-level security](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/J4lKLg) is configured, issue-level security permission to view the issue.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
jql_get_response = atlassianjira.issue_search.jql_get(
    jql="project = HSP",
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
    validate_query="strict",
    fields=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    expand="string_example",
    properties=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    fields_by_keys=False,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### jql: `str`<a id="jql-str"></a>

The [JQL](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/egORLQ) that defines the search. Note:   *  If no JQL expression is provided, all issues are returned.  *  `username` and `userkey` cannot be used as search terms due to privacy reasons. Use `accountId` instead.  *  If a user has hidden their email address in their user profile, partial matches of the email address will not find the user. An exact match is required.

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page. To manage page size, Jira may return fewer items per page where a large number of fields are requested. The greatest number of items returned per page is achieved when requesting `id` or `key` only.

##### validate_query: `str`<a id="validate_query-str"></a>

Determines how to validate the JQL query and treat the validation results. Supported values are:   *  `strict` Returns a 400 response code if any errors are found, along with a list of all errors (and warnings).  *  `warn` Returns all errors as warnings.  *  `none` No validation is performed.  *  `true` *Deprecated* A legacy synonym for `strict`.  *  `false` *Deprecated* A legacy synonym for `warn`.  Note: If the JQL is not correctly formed a 400 response code is returned, regardless of the `validateQuery` value.

##### fields: List[`str`]<a id="fields-liststr"></a>

A list of fields to return for each issue, use it to retrieve a subset of fields. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Expand options include:   *  `*all` Returns all fields.  *  `*navigable` Returns navigable fields.  *  Any issue field, prefixed with a minus to exclude.  Examples:   *  `summary,comment` Returns only the summary and comments fields.  *  `-description` Returns all navigable (default) fields except description.  *  `*all,-comment` Returns all fields except comments.  This parameter may be specified multiple times. For example, `fields=field1,field2&fields=field3`.  Note: All navigable fields are returned by default. This differs from [GET issue](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) where the default is all fields.

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use [expand](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to include additional information about issues in the response. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Expand options include:   *  `renderedFields` Returns field values rendered in HTML format.  *  `names` Returns the display name of each field.  *  `schema` Returns the schema describing a field type.  *  `transitions` Returns all possible transitions for the issue.  *  `operations` Returns all possible operations for the issue.  *  `editmeta` Returns information about how each field can be edited.  *  `changelog` Returns a list of recent updates to an issue, sorted by date, starting from the most recent.  *  `versionedRepresentations` Instead of `fields`, returns `versionedRepresentations` a JSON array containing each version of a field's value, with the highest numbered item representing the most recent version.

##### properties: List[`str`]<a id="properties-liststr"></a>

A list of issue property keys for issue properties to include in the results. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Multiple properties can also be provided using an ampersand separated list. For example, `properties=prop1,prop2&properties=prop3`. A maximum of 5 issue property keys can be specified.

##### fields_by_keys: `bool`<a id="fields_by_keys-bool"></a>

Reference fields by their key (rather than ID).

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`SearchResults`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/search_results.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/search` `get`

[🔙 **Back to Table of Contents**](#table-of-contents)

### `atlassianjira.issue_search.picker_suggestions_get`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_searchpicker_suggestions_get"></a>

Returns lists of issues matching a query string. Use this resource to provide auto-completion suggestions when the user is looking for an issue using a word or string.

This operation returns two lists:

 *  `History Search` which includes issues from the user's history of created, edited, or viewed issues that contain the string in the `query` parameter.
 *  `Current Search` which includes issues that match the JQL expression in `currentJQL` and contain the string in the `query` parameter.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** None.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
picker_suggestions_get_response = atlassianjira.issue_search.picker_suggestions_get(
    query="query",
    current_jql="string_example",
    current_issue_key="string_example",
    current_project_id="string_example",
    show_sub_tasks=True,
    show_sub_task_parent=True,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

A string to match against text fields in the issue such as title, description, or comments.

##### current_jql: `str`<a id="current_jql-str"></a>

A JQL query defining a list of issues to search for the query term. Note that `username` and `userkey` cannot be used as search terms for this parameter, due to privacy reasons. Use `accountId` instead.

##### current_issue_key: `str`<a id="current_issue_key-str"></a>

The key of an issue to exclude from search results. For example, the issue the user is viewing when they perform this query.

##### current_project_id: `str`<a id="current_project_id-str"></a>

The ID of a project that suggested issues must belong to.

##### show_sub_tasks: `bool`<a id="show_sub_tasks-bool"></a>

Indicate whether to include subtasks in the suggestions list.

##### show_sub_task_parent: `bool`<a id="show_sub_task_parent-bool"></a>

When `currentIssueKey` is a subtask, whether to include the parent issue in the suggestions if it matches the query.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`IssuePickerSuggestions`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/issue_picker_suggestions.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/issue/picker` `get`

### `atlassianjira.issue_search.search_issue_ids_using_jql_post`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_searchsearch_issue_ids_using_jql_post"></a>

Searches for IDs of issues using [JQL](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/egORLQ).

Use the [Search](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) endpoint if you need to fetch more than just issue IDs. The Search endpoint returns more information, but may take much longer to respond to requests. This is because it uses a different mechanism for ordering results than this endpoint and doesn't provide the total number of results for your query.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Issues are included in the response where the user has:

 *  *Browse projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project containing the issue.
 *  If [issue-level security](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/J4lKLg) is configured, issue-level security permission to view the issue.

```python

    jql="string_example",
    max_results=1000,
    next_page_token="string_example",
)
```

A [JQL](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/egORLQ) expression. Order by clauses are not allowed.

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### next_page_token: `str`<a id="next_page_token-str"></a>

The continuation token to fetch the next page. This token is provided by the response of this endpoint.

### `atlassianjira.issue_security_level.get_level_members`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_security_levelget_level_members"></a>

Returns issue security level members.

Only issue security level members in context of classic projects are returned.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_level_members_response = atlassianjira.issue_security_level.get_level_members(
    issue_security_scheme_id=1,
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
    issue_security_level_id=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    expand="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### issue_security_scheme_id: `int`<a id="issue_security_scheme_id-int"></a>

The ID of the issue security scheme. Use the [Get issue security schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) operation to get a list of issue security scheme IDs.

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### issue_security_level_id: List[`str`]<a id="issue_security_level_id-liststr"></a>

The list of issue security level IDs. To include multiple issue security levels separate IDs with ampersand: `issueSecurityLevelId=10000&issueSecurityLevelId=10001`.

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use expand to include additional information in the response. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Expand options include:   *  `all` Returns all expandable information.  *  `field` Returns information about the custom field granted the permission.  *  `group` Returns information about the group that is granted the permission.  *  `projectRole` Returns information about the project role granted the permission.  *  `user` Returns information about the user who is granted the permission.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`PageBeanIssueSecurityLevelMember`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/page_bean_issue_security_level_member.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/issuesecurityschemes/{issueSecuritySchemeId}/members` `get`

### `atlassianjira.issue_security_schemes.associate_scheme_to_project`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_security_schemesassociate_scheme_to_project"></a>

Associates an issue security scheme with a project and remaps security levels of issues to the new levels, if provided.

This operation is [asynchronous](https://dac-static.atlassian.com). Follow the `location` link in the response to determine the status of the task and use [Get task](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to obtain subsequent updates.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
atlassianjira.issue_security_schemes.associate_scheme_to_project(
    project_id="string_example",
    scheme_id="string_example",
    old_to_new_security_level_mappings=[
        {
            "new_level_id": "new_level_id_example",
            "old_level_id": "old_level_id_example",
        }
    ],
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### project_id: `str`<a id="project_id-str"></a>

The ID of the project.

##### scheme_id: `str`<a id="scheme_id-str"></a>

The ID of the issue security scheme. Providing null will clear the association with the issue security scheme.

##### old_to_new_security_level_mappings: List[`OldToNewSecurityLevelMappingsBean`]<a id="old_to_new_security_level_mappings-listoldtonewsecuritylevelmappingsbean"></a>

The list of scheme levels which should be remapped to new levels of the issue security scheme.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`AssociateSecuritySchemeWithProjectDetails`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/associate_security_scheme_with_project_details.py)
#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/issuesecurityschemes/project` `put`

```python
    ],
    expand="string_example",
)
```

The list of issue security scheme IDs. To include multiple issue security schemes separate IDs with an ampersand: `schemeId=10000&schemeId=10001`.

### `atlassianjira.issue_security_schemes.get_security_levels`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_security_schemesget_security_levels"></a>

Returns a [paginated](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) list of issue security levels.

Only issue security levels in the context of classic projects are returned.

Filtering using IDs is inclusive: if you specify both security scheme IDs and level IDs, the result will include both specified issue security levels and all issue security levels from the specified schemes.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_security_levels_response = atlassianjira.issue_security_schemes.get_security_levels(
    start_at="0",
    max_results="50",
    id=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    scheme_id=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    only_default=False,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### start_at: `str`<a id="start_at-str"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `str`<a id="max_results-str"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### id: List[`str`]<a id="id-liststr"></a>

The list of issue security scheme level IDs. To include multiple issue security levels, separate IDs with an ampersand: `id=10000&id=10001`.

##### scheme_id: List[`str`]<a id="scheme_id-liststr"></a>

The list of issue security scheme IDs. To include multiple issue security schemes, separate IDs with an ampersand: `schemeId=10000&schemeId=10001`.

##### only_default: `bool`<a id="only_default-bool"></a>

When set to true, returns multiple default levels for each security scheme containing a default. If you provide scheme and level IDs not associated with the default, returns an empty page. The default value is false.

### `atlassianjira.issue_type_schemes.change_order_of_issue_types`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_type_schemeschange_order_of_issue_types"></a>

Changes the order of issue types in an issue type scheme.

The request body parameters must meet the following requirements:

 *  all of the issue types must belong to the issue type scheme.
 *  either `after` or `position` must be provided.
 *  the issue type in `after` must not be in the issue type list.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

```python
change_order_of_issue_types_response = atlassianjira.issue_type_schemes.change_order_of_issue_types(
    issue_type_ids=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    issue_type_scheme_id=1,
    after="string_example",
    position="First",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### issue_type_ids: [`OrderOfIssueTypesIssueTypeIds`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/order_of_issue_types_issue_type_ids.py)<a id="issue_type_ids-orderofissuetypesissuetypeidsatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeorder_of_issue_types_issue_type_idspy"></a>

##### issue_type_scheme_id: `int`<a id="issue_type_scheme_id-int"></a>

The ID of the issue type scheme.

##### after: `str`<a id="after-str"></a>

The ID of the issue type to place the moved issue types after. Required if `position` isn't provided.

##### position: `str`<a id="position-str"></a>

The position the issue types should be moved to. Required if `after` isn't provided.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`OrderOfIssueTypes`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/order_of_issue_types.py)

### `atlassianjira.issue_type_schemes.get_all_schemes`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_type_schemesget_all_schemes"></a>

Returns a [paginated](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) list of issue type schemes.

Only issue type schemes used in classic projects are returned.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_all_schemes_response = atlassianjira.issue_type_schemes.get_all_schemes(
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
    id=[
        1
    ],
    order_by="id",
    expand="",
    query_string="",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### id: List[`int`]<a id="id-listint"></a>

The list of issue type schemes IDs. To include multiple IDs, provide an ampersand-separated list. For example, `id=10000&id=10001`.

##### order_by: `str`<a id="order_by-str"></a>

[Order](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) the results by a field:   *  `name` Sorts by issue type scheme name.  *  `id` Sorts by issue type scheme ID.

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use [expand](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to include additional information in the response. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Expand options include:   *  `projects` For each issue type schemes, returns information about the projects the issue type scheme is assigned to.  *  `issueTypes` For each issue type schemes, returns information about the issueTypes the issue type scheme have.

##### query_string: `str`<a id="query_string-str"></a>

String used to perform a case-insensitive partial match with issue type scheme name.

[`PageBeanIssueTypeScheme`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/page_bean_issue_type_scheme.py)

### `atlassianjira.issue_types.load_issue_type_avatar`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_typesload_issue_type_avatar"></a>

Loads an avatar for the issue type.

Specify the avatar's local file location in the body of the request. Also, include the following headers:

 *  `X-Atlassian-Token: no-check` To prevent XSRF protection blocking the request, for more information see [Special Headers](https://dac-static.atlassian.com).
 *  `Content-Type: image/image type` Valid image types are JPEG, GIF, or PNG.

For example:  
`curl --request POST \ --user email@example.com:<api_token> \ --header 'X-Atlassian-Token: no-check' \ --header 'Content-Type: image/< image_type>' \ --data-binary "<@/path/to/file/with/your/avatar>" \ --url 'https://your-domain.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/issuetype/{issueTypeId}'This`

The avatar is cropped to a square. If no crop parameters are specified, the square originates at the top left of the image. The length of the square's sides is set to the smaller of the height or width of the image.

The cropped image is then used to create avatars of 16x16, 24x24, 32x32, and 48x48 in size.

After creating the avatar, use [Update issue type](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to set it as the issue type's displayed avatar.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
load_issue_type_avatar_response = atlassianjira.issue_types.load_issue_type_avatar(
    body=None,
    id="id_example",
    size=1,
    x=0,
    y=0,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### id: `str`<a id="id-str"></a>

The ID of the issue type.

##### size: `int`<a id="size-int"></a>

The length of each side of the crop region.

##### x: `int`<a id="x-int"></a>

The X coordinate of the top-left corner of the crop region.

##### y: `int`<a id="y-int"></a>

The Y coordinate of the top-left corner of the crop region.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

`Union[bool, date, datetime, dict, float, int, list, str, None]`
#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`Avatar`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/avatar.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/issuetype/{id}/avatar2` `post`

 *  *Edit all worklogs*[project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) to update any worklog or *Edit own worklogs* to update worklogs created by the user.
 *  If the worklog has visibility restrictions, belongs to the group or has the role visibility is restricted to.

### `atlassianjira.issue_worklogs.create_worklog`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_worklogscreate_worklog"></a>

Adds a worklog to an issue.

Time tracking must be enabled in Jira, otherwise this operation returns an error. For more information, see [Configuring time tracking](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/qoXKM).

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:**

 *  *Browse projects* and *Work on issues* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project that the issue is in.
 *  If [issue-level security](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/J4lKLg) is configured, issue-level security permission to view the issue.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
create_worklog_response = atlassianjira.issue_worklogs.create_worklog(
    issue_id_or_key="issueIdOrKey_example",
    author={
    },
    comment=None,
    created="1970-01-01T00:00:00.00Z",
    id="string_example",
    issue_id="string_example",
    properties=[
        {
        }
    ],
    _self="string_example",
    started="1970-01-01T00:00:00.00Z",
    time_spent="string_example",
    time_spent_seconds=1,
    update_author={
    },
    updated="1970-01-01T00:00:00.00Z",
    visibility={
        "type": "group",
    },
    notify_users=True,
    adjust_estimate="auto",
    new_estimate="string_example",
    reduce_by="string_example",
    expand="",
    override_editable_flag=False,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### issue_id_or_key: `str`<a id="issue_id_or_key-str"></a>

The ID or key the issue.

##### author: [`UserDetails`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/user_details.py)<a id="author-userdetailsatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeuser_detailspy"></a>


##### comment: [`Union[bool, date, datetime, dict, float, int, list, str, None]`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/typing_union_bool_date_datetime_dict_float_int_list_str_none.py)<a id="comment-unionbool-date-datetime-dict-float-int-list-str-noneatlassian_jira_python_sdktypetyping_union_bool_date_datetime_dict_float_int_list_str_nonepy"></a>

A comment about the worklog in [Atlassian Document Format](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/apis/document/structure/). Optional when creating or updating a worklog.

##### created: `datetime`<a id="created-datetime"></a>

The datetime on which the worklog was created.

##### id: `str`<a id="id-str"></a>

The ID of the worklog record.

##### issue_id: `str`<a id="issue_id-str"></a>

The ID of the issue this worklog is for.

##### properties: List[`EntityProperty`]<a id="properties-listentityproperty"></a>

Details of properties for the worklog. Optional when creating or updating a worklog.

##### _self: `str`<a id="_self-str"></a>

The URL of the worklog item.

##### started: `datetime`<a id="started-datetime"></a>

The datetime on which the worklog effort was started. Required when creating a worklog. Optional when updating a worklog.

##### time_spent: `str`<a id="time_spent-str"></a>

The time spent working on the issue as days (\\\\#d), hours (\\\\#h), or minutes (\\\\#m or \\\\#). Required when creating a worklog if `timeSpentSeconds` isn't provided. Optional when updating a worklog. Cannot be provided if `timeSpentSecond` is provided.

##### time_spent_seconds: `int`<a id="time_spent_seconds-int"></a>

The time in seconds spent working on the issue. Required when creating a worklog if `timeSpent` isn't provided. Optional when updating a worklog. Cannot be provided if `timeSpent` is provided.

##### update_author: [`UserDetails`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/user_details.py)<a id="update_author-userdetailsatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeuser_detailspy"></a>


##### updated: `datetime`<a id="updated-datetime"></a>

The datetime on which the worklog was last updated.

##### visibility: [`Visibility`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/visibility.py)<a id="visibility-visibilityatlassian_jira_python_sdktypevisibilitypy"></a>


##### notify_users: `bool`<a id="notify_users-bool"></a>

Whether users watching the issue are notified by email.

##### adjust_estimate: `str`<a id="adjust_estimate-str"></a>

Defines how to update the issue's time estimate, the options are:   *  `new` Sets the estimate to a specific value, defined in `newEstimate`.  *  `leave` Leaves the estimate unchanged.  *  `manual` Reduces the estimate by amount specified in `reduceBy`.  *  `auto` Reduces the estimate by the value of `timeSpent` in the worklog.

##### new_estimate: `str`<a id="new_estimate-str"></a>

The value to set as the issue's remaining time estimate, as days (\\#d), hours (\\#h), or minutes (\\#m or \\#). For example, *2d*. Required when `adjustEstimate` is `new`.

##### reduce_by: `str`<a id="reduce_by-str"></a>

The amount to reduce the issue's remaining estimate by, as days (\\#d), hours (\\#h), or minutes (\\#m). For example, *2d*. Required when `adjustEstimate` is `manual`.

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use [expand](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to include additional information about work logs in the response. This parameter accepts `properties`, which returns worklog properties.

##### override_editable_flag: `bool`<a id="override_editable_flag-bool"></a>

Whether the worklog entry should be added to the issue even if the issue is not editable, because jira.issue.editable set to false or missing. For example, the issue is closed. Connect and Forge app users with *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg) can use this flag.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`Worklog`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/worklog.py)
#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`Worklog`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/worklog.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/issue/{issueIdOrKey}/worklog` `post`

```python
get_details_for_list_response = atlassianjira.issue_worklogs.get_details_for_list(
```

### `atlassianjira.issue_worklogs.get_updated_worklog_ids`<a id="atlassianjiraissue_worklogsget_updated_worklog_ids"></a>

Returns a list of IDs and update timestamps for worklogs updated after a date and time.

This resource is paginated, with a limit of 1000 worklogs per page. Each page lists worklogs from oldest to youngest. If the number of items in the date range exceeds 1000, `until` indicates the timestamp of the youngest item on the page. Also, `nextPage` provides the URL for the next page of worklogs. The `lastPage` parameter is set to true on the last page of worklogs.

This resource does not return worklogs updated during the minute preceding the request.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Permission to access Jira, however, worklogs are only returned where either of the following is true:

 *  the worklog is set as *Viewable by All Users*.
 *  the user is a member of a project role or group with permission to view the worklog.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_updated_worklog_ids_response = atlassianjira.issue_worklogs.get_updated_worklog_ids(
    since=0,
    expand="",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### since: `int`<a id="since-int"></a>

The date and time, as a UNIX timestamp in milliseconds, after which updated worklogs are returned.

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use [expand](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to include additional information about worklogs in the response. This parameter accepts `properties` that returns the properties of each worklog.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`ChangedWorklogs`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/changed_worklogs.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/worklog/updated` `get`

### `atlassianjira.issues.archive_by_ids_put`<a id="atlassianjiraissuesarchive_by_ids_put"></a>

Enables admins to archive up to 1000 issues in a single request using issue ID/key, returning details of the issue(s) archived in the process and the errors encountered, if any.

**Note that:**

 *  you can't archive subtasks directly, only through their parent issues
 *  you can only archive issues from software, service management, and business projects

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Jira admin or site admin: [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg)

**License required:** Premium or Enterprise

**Signed-in users only:** This API can't be accessed anonymously.

  


#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

### `atlassianjira.issues.archive_by_jql_post`<a id="atlassianjiraissuesarchive_by_jql_post"></a>

Enables admins to archive up to 100,000 issues in a single request using JQL, returning the URL to check the status of the submitted request.

You can use the [get task](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/rest/v3/api-group-tasks/#api-rest-api-3-task-taskid-get) and [cancel task](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/rest/v3/api-group-tasks/#api-rest-api-3-task-taskid-cancel-post) APIs to manage the request.

**Note that:**

 *  you can't archive subtasks directly, only through their parent issues
 *  you can only archive issues from software, service management, and business projects

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Jira admin or site admin: [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg)

**License required:** Premium or Enterprise

**Signed-in users only:** This API can't be accessed anonymously.

**Rate limiting:** Only a single request per jira instance can be active at any given time.

  


#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
archive_by_jql_post_response = atlassianjira.issues.archive_by_jql_post(
```

### `atlassianjira.issues.assign_issue_to_user`<a id="atlassianjiraissuesassign_issue_to_user"></a>

Assigns an issue to a user. Use this operation when the calling user does not have the *Edit Issues* permission but has the *Assign issue* permission for the project that the issue is in.

If `name` or `accountId` is set to:

 *  `"-1"`, the issue is assigned to the default assignee for the project.
 *  `null`, the issue is set to unassigned.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:**

 *  *Browse Projects* and *Assign Issues* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project that the issue is in.
 *  If [issue-level security](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/J4lKLg) is configured, issue-level security permission to view the issue.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
assign_issue_to_user_response = atlassianjira.issues.assign_issue_to_user(
    issue_id_or_key="issueIdOrKey_example",
    account_id="string_example",
    account_type="atlassian",
    active=True,
    application_roles={
    },
    avatar_urls={
    },
    display_name="string_example",
    email_address="string_example",
    expand="string_example",
    groups={
    },
    key="string_example",
    locale="string_example",
    name="string_example",
    _self="string_example",
    time_zone="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### issue_id_or_key: `str`<a id="issue_id_or_key-str"></a>

The ID or key of the issue to be assigned.

##### account_id: `str`<a id="account_id-str"></a>

The account ID of the user, which uniquely identifies the user across all Atlassian products. For example, *5b10ac8d82e05b22cc7d4ef5*. Required in requests.

##### account_type: `str`<a id="account_type-str"></a>

The user account type. Can take the following values:   *  `atlassian` regular Atlassian user account  *  `app` system account used for Connect applications and OAuth to represent external systems  *  `customer` Jira Service Desk account representing an external service desk

##### active: `bool`<a id="active-bool"></a>

Whether the user is active.

##### application_roles: [`SimpleListWrapperApplicationRole`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/simple_list_wrapper_application_role.py)<a id="application_roles-simplelistwrapperapplicationroleatlassian_jira_python_sdktypesimple_list_wrapper_application_rolepy"></a>


The application roles the user is assigned to.

##### avatar_urls: [`AvatarUrlsBean`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/avatar_urls_bean.py)<a id="avatar_urls-avatarurlsbeanatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeavatar_urls_beanpy"></a>


The avatars of the user.

##### display_name: `str`<a id="display_name-str"></a>

The display name of the user. Depending on the user’s privacy setting, this may return an alternative value.

##### email_address: `str`<a id="email_address-str"></a>

### `atlassianjira.issues.bulk_create_issue`<a id="atlassianjiraissuesbulk_create_issue"></a>

Creates upto **50** issues and, where the option to create subtasks is enabled in Jira, subtasks. Transitions may be applied, to move the issues or subtasks to a workflow step other than the default start step, and issue properties set.

The content of each issue or subtask is defined using `update` and `fields`. The fields that can be set in the issue or subtask are determined using the [Get create issue metadata](https://dac-static.atlassian.com). These are the same fields that appear on the issues' create screens. Note that the `description`, `environment`, and any `textarea` type custom fields (multi-line text fields) take Atlassian Document Format content. Single line custom fields (`textfield`) accept a string and don't handle Atlassian Document Format content.

Creating a subtask differs from creating an issue as follows:

 *  `issueType` must be set to a subtask issue type (use [Get create issue metadata](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to find subtask issue types).
 *  `parent` the must contain the ID or key of the parent issue.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Browse projects* and *Create issues* [project permissions](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project in which each issue or subtask is created.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
bulk_create_issue_response = atlassianjira.issues.bulk_create_issue(
    issue_updates=[
        {
        }
    ],
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

[`IssuesUpdateBean`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issues_update_bean.py)
#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>
