### `atlassianjira.project_versions.create_project_version`<a id="atlassianjiraproject_versionscreate_project_version"></a>

Creates a project version.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg) or *Administer Projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project the version is added to.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
create_project_version_response = atlassianjira.project_versions.create_project_version(
    description="string_example",
    approvers=[
        {
        }
    ],
    archived=True,
    driver="string_example",
    expand="string_example",
    id="string_example",
    issues_status_for_fix_version={
    },
    move_unfixed_issues_to="string_example",
    name="string_example",
    operations=[
        {
        }
    ],
    overdue=True,
    project="string_example",
    project_id=1,
    release_date="1970-01-01",
    released=True,
    _self="string_example",
    start_date="1970-01-01",
    user_release_date="string_example",
    user_start_date="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### description: `str`<a id="description-str"></a>

The description of the version. Optional when creating or updating a version. The maximum size is 16,384 bytes.

##### approvers: List[`VersionApprover`]<a id="approvers-listversionapprover"></a>

If the expand option `approvers` is used, returns a list containing the approvers for this version.

##### archived: `bool`<a id="archived-bool"></a>

Indicates that the version is archived. Optional when creating or updating a version.

##### driver: `str`<a id="driver-str"></a>

If the expand option `driver` is used, returns the Atlassian account ID of the driver.

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use [expand](em>#expansion) to include additional information about version in the response. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Expand options include:   *  `operations` Returns the list of operations available for this version.  *  `issuesstatus` Returns the count of issues in this version for each of the status categories *to do*, *in progress*, *done*, and *unmapped*. The *unmapped* property contains a count of issues with a status other than *to do*, *in progress*, and *done*.  *  `driver` Returns the Atlassian account ID of the version driver.  *  `approvers` Returns a list containing approvers for this version.  Optional for create and update.

##### id: `str`<a id="id-str"></a>

The ID of the version.

##### issues_status_for_fix_version: [`VersionIssuesStatus`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/version_issues_status.py)<a id="issues_status_for_fix_version-versionissuesstatusatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeversion_issues_statuspy"></a>


If the expand option `issuesstatus` is used, returns the count of issues in this version for each of the status categories *to do*, *in progress*, *done*, and *unmapped*. The *unmapped* property contains a count of issues with a status other than *to do*, *in progress*, and *done*.

##### move_unfixed_issues_to: `str`<a id="move_unfixed_issues_to-str"></a>

The URL of the self link to the version to which all unfixed issues are moved when a version is released. Not applicable when creating a version. Optional when updating a version.

##### name: `str`<a id="name-str"></a>

The unique name of the version. Required when creating a version. Optional when updating a version. The maximum length is 255 characters.

##### operations: List[`SimpleLink`]<a id="operations-listsimplelink"></a>

If the expand option `operations` is used, returns the list of operations available for this version.

##### overdue: `bool`<a id="overdue-bool"></a>

Indicates that the version is overdue.

##### project: `str`<a id="project-str"></a>

Deprecated. Use `projectId`.

##### project_id: `int`<a id="project_id-int"></a>

The ID of the project to which this version is attached. Required when creating a version. Not applicable when updating a version.

##### release_date: `date`<a id="release_date-date"></a>

The release date of the version. Expressed in ISO 8601 format (yyyy-mm-dd). Optional when creating or updating a version.

##### released: `bool`<a id="released-bool"></a>

Indicates that the version is released. If the version is released a request to release again is ignored. Not applicable when creating a version. Optional when updating a version.

##### _self: `str`<a id="_self-str"></a>

The URL of the version.

##### start_date: `date`<a id="start_date-date"></a>

The start date of the version. Expressed in ISO 8601 format (yyyy-mm-dd). Optional when creating or updating a version.

##### user_release_date: `str`<a id="user_release_date-str"></a>

The date on which work on this version is expected to finish, expressed in the instance's *Day/Month/Year Format* date format.

##### user_start_date: `str`<a id="user_start_date-str"></a>

The date on which work on this version is expected to start, expressed in the instance's *Day/Month/Year Format* date format.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`Version`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/version.py)
#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`Version`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/version.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/version` `post`

### `atlassianjira.project_versions.delete_and_replace_version`<a id="atlassianjiraproject_versionsdelete_and_replace_version"></a>

Deletes a project version.

Alternative versions can be provided to update issues that use the deleted version in `fixVersion`, `affectedVersion`, or any version picker custom fields. If alternatives are not provided, occurrences of `fixVersion`, `affectedVersion`, and any version picker custom field, that contain the deleted version, are cleared. Any replacement version must be in the same project as the version being deleted and cannot be the version being deleted.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg) or *Administer Projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project that contains the version.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
delete_and_replace_version_response = atlassianjira.project_versions.delete_and_replace_version(
    id="id_example",
    custom_field_replacement_list=[
        {
        }
    ],
    move_affected_issues_to=1,
    move_fix_issues_to=1,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### id: `str`<a id="id-str"></a>

The ID of the version.

##### custom_field_replacement_list: List[`CustomFieldReplacement`]<a id="custom_field_replacement_list-listcustomfieldreplacement"></a>

An array of custom field IDs (`customFieldId`) and version IDs (`moveTo`) to update when the fields contain the deleted version.

##### move_affected_issues_to: `int`<a id="move_affected_issues_to-int"></a>

The ID of the version to update `affectedVersion` to when the field contains the deleted version.

##### move_fix_issues_to: `int`<a id="move_fix_issues_to-int"></a>

The ID of the version to update `fixVersion` to when the field contains the deleted version.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`DeleteAndReplaceVersionBean`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/delete_and_replace_version_bean.py)

### `atlassianjira.project_versions.list_paginated`<a id="atlassianjiraproject_versionslist_paginated"></a>

Returns a [paginated](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) list of all versions in a project. See the [Get project versions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource if you want to get a full list of versions without pagination.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Browse Projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
list_paginated_response = atlassianjira.project_versions.list_paginated(
    project_id_or_key="projectIdOrKey_example",
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
    order_by="description",
    query="string_example",
    status="string_example",
    expand="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### project_id_or_key: `str`<a id="project_id_or_key-str"></a>

The project ID or project key (case sensitive).

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### order_by: `str`<a id="order_by-str"></a>

[Order](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) the results by a field:   *  `description` Sorts by version description.  *  `name` Sorts by version name.  *  `releaseDate` Sorts by release date, starting with the oldest date. Versions with no release date are listed last.  *  `sequence` Sorts by the order of appearance in the user interface.  *  `startDate` Sorts by start date, starting with the oldest date. Versions with no start date are listed last.

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

Filter the results using a literal string. Versions with matching `name` or `description` are returned (case insensitive).

##### status: `str`<a id="status-str"></a>

A list of status values used to filter the results by version status. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. The status values are `released`, `unreleased`, and `archived`.

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use [expand](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to include additional information in the response. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Expand options include:   *  `issuesstatus` Returns the number of issues in each status category for each version.  *  `operations` Returns actions that can be performed on the specified version.  *  `driver` Returns the Atlassian account ID of the version driver.  *  `approvers` Returns a list containing the approvers for this version.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`PageBeanVersion`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/page_bean_version.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/project/{projectIdOrKey}/version` `get`

### `atlassianjira.project_versions.merge_versions`<a id="atlassianjiraproject_versionsmerge_versions"></a>

Merges two project versions. The merge is completed by deleting the version specified in `id` and replacing any occurrences of its ID in `fixVersion` with the version ID specified in `moveIssuesTo`.

Consider using [Delete and replace version](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) instead. This resource supports swapping version values in `fixVersion`, `affectedVersion`, and custom fields.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg) or *Administer Projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project that contains the version.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
merge_versions_response = atlassianjira.project_versions.merge_versions(
    id="id_example",
    move_issues_to="moveIssuesTo_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### id: `str`<a id="id-str"></a>

The ID of the version to delete.

##### move_issues_to: `str`<a id="move_issues_to-str"></a>

The ID of the version to merge into.

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/version/{id}/mergeto/{moveIssuesTo}` `put`

### `atlassianjira.projects.create_project_based_on_template`<a id="atlassianjiraprojectscreate_project_based_on_template"></a>

Creates a project based on a project type template, as shown in the following table:

| Project Type Key | Project Template Key |  
|--|--|  
| `business` | `com.atlassian.jira-core-project-templates:jira-core-simplified-content-management`, `com.atlassian.jira-core-project-templates:jira-core-simplified-document-approval`, `com.atlassian.jira-core-project-templates:jira-core-simplified-lead-tracking`, `com.atlassian.jira-core-project-templates:jira-core-simplified-process-control`, `com.atlassian.jira-core-project-templates:jira-core-simplified-procurement`, `com.atlassian.jira-core-project-templates:jira-core-simplified-project-management`, `com.atlassian.jira-core-project-templates:jira-core-simplified-recruitment`, `com.atlassian.jira-core-project-templates:jira-core-simplified-task-tracking` |  
| `service_desk` | `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-it-service-management`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-general-service-desk-it`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-general-service-desk-business`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-external-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-hr-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-facilities-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-legal-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-analytics-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-marketing-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-design-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-sales-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-blank-project-business`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-blank-project-it`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:simplified-finance-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-it-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-hr-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-legal-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-marketing-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-facilities-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-general-it-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-general-business-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-analytics-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-finance-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-design-service-desk`, `com.atlassian.servicedesk:next-gen-sales-service-desk` |  
| `software` | `com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-simplified-agility-kanban`, `com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-simplified-agility-scrum`, `com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-simplified-basic`, `com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-simplified-kanban-classic`, `com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-simplified-scrum-classic` |  
The project types are available according to the installed Jira features as follows:

 *  Jira Core, the default, enables `business` projects.
 *  Jira Service Management enables `service_desk` projects.
 *  Jira Software enables `software` projects.

To determine which features are installed, go to **Jira settings** > **Apps** > **Manage apps** and review the System Apps list. To add Jira Software or Jira Service Management into a JIRA instance, use **Jira settings** > **Apps** > **Finding new apps**. For more information, see [Managing add-ons](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/S31NLg).

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
create_project_based_on_template_response = atlassianjira.projects.create_project_based_on_template(
    key="string_example",
    name="string_example",
    description="string_example",
    assignee_type="PROJECT_LEAD",
    avatar_id=1,
    category_id=1,
    field_configuration_scheme=1,
    issue_security_scheme=1,
    issue_type_scheme=1,
    issue_type_screen_scheme=1,
    lead="string_example",
    lead_account_id="string_example",
    notification_scheme=1,
    permission_scheme=1,
    project_template_key="com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-simplified-agility-kanban",
    project_type_key="software",
    url="string_example",
    workflow_scheme=1,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### key: `str`<a id="key-str"></a>

Project keys must be unique and start with an uppercase letter followed by one or more uppercase alphanumeric characters. The maximum length is 10 characters.

##### name: `str`<a id="name-str"></a>

The name of the project.

##### description: `str`<a id="description-str"></a>

A brief description of the project.

##### assignee_type: `str`<a id="assignee_type-str"></a>

The default assignee when creating issues for this project.

##### avatar_id: `int`<a id="avatar_id-int"></a>

An integer value for the project's avatar.

##### category_id: `int`<a id="category_id-int"></a>

The ID of the project's category. A complete list of category IDs is found using the [Get all project categories](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) operation.

##### field_configuration_scheme: `int`<a id="field_configuration_scheme-int"></a>

The ID of the field configuration scheme for the project. Use the [Get all field configuration schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) operation to get a list of field configuration scheme IDs. If you specify the field configuration scheme you cannot specify the project template key.

##### issue_security_scheme: `int`<a id="issue_security_scheme-int"></a>

The ID of the issue security scheme for the project, which enables you to control who can and cannot view issues. Use the [Get issue security schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource to get all issue security scheme IDs.

##### issue_type_scheme: `int`<a id="issue_type_scheme-int"></a>

The ID of the issue type scheme for the project. Use the [Get all issue type schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) operation to get a list of issue type scheme IDs. If you specify the issue type scheme you cannot specify the project template key.

##### issue_type_screen_scheme: `int`<a id="issue_type_screen_scheme-int"></a>

The ID of the issue type screen scheme for the project. Use the [Get all issue type screen schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) operation to get a list of issue type screen scheme IDs. If you specify the issue type screen scheme you cannot specify the project template key.

##### lead: `str`<a id="lead-str"></a>

This parameter is deprecated because of privacy changes. Use `leadAccountId` instead. See the [migration guide](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/deprecation-notice-user-privacy-api-migration-guide/) for details. The user name of the project lead. Either `lead` or `leadAccountId` must be set when creating a project. Cannot be provided with `leadAccountId`.

##### lead_account_id: `str`<a id="lead_account_id-str"></a>

The account ID of the project lead. Either `lead` or `leadAccountId` must be set when creating a project. Cannot be provided with `lead`.

##### notification_scheme: `int`<a id="notification_scheme-int"></a>

The ID of the notification scheme for the project. Use the [Get notification schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource to get a list of notification scheme IDs.

##### permission_scheme: `int`<a id="permission_scheme-int"></a>

The ID of the permission scheme for the project. Use the [Get all permission schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource to see a list of all permission scheme IDs.

##### project_template_key: `str`<a id="project_template_key-str"></a>

A predefined configuration for a project. The type of the `projectTemplateKey` must match with the type of the `projectTypeKey`.

##### project_type_key: `str`<a id="project_type_key-str"></a>

The [project type](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/GwiiLQ#Jiraapplicationsoverview-Productfeaturesandprojecttypes), which defines the application-specific feature set. If you don't specify the project template you have to specify the project type.

##### url: `str`<a id="url-str"></a>

A link to information about this project, such as project documentation

##### workflow_scheme: `int`<a id="workflow_scheme-int"></a>

The ID of the workflow scheme for the project. Use the [Get all workflow schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) operation to get a list of workflow scheme IDs. If you specify the workflow scheme you cannot specify the project template key.

The JSON representation of the project being created.

### `atlassianjira.projects.get_issue_type_hierarchy`<a id="atlassianjiraprojectsget_issue_type_hierarchy"></a>

Get the issue type hierarchy for a next-gen project.

The issue type hierarchy for a project consists of:

 *  *Epic* at level 1 (optional).
 *  One or more issue types at level 0 such as *Story*, *Task*, or *Bug*. Where the issue type *Epic* is defined, these issue types are used to break down the content of an epic.
 *  *Subtask* at level -1 (optional). This issue type enables level 0 issue types to be broken down into components. Issues based on a level -1 issue type must have a parent issue.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Browse projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_issue_type_hierarchy_response = atlassianjira.projects.get_issue_type_hierarchy(
    project_id=1,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### project_id: `int`<a id="project_id-int"></a>

The ID of the project.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`ProjectIssueTypeHierarchy`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/project_issue_type_hierarchy.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/project/{projectId}/hierarchy` `get`

### `atlassianjira.projects.list_visible_projects`<a id="atlassianjiraprojectslist_visible_projects"></a>

Returns a [paginated](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) list of projects visible to the user.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Projects are returned only where the user has one of:

 *  *Browse Projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project.
 *  *Administer Projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project.
 *  *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
list_visible_projects_response = atlassianjira.projects.list_visible_projects(
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
    order_by="key",
    id=[
        1
    ],
    keys=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    query="string_example",
    type_key="string_example",
    category_id=1,
    action="view",
    expand="string_example",
    status=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    properties=[
        {}
    ],
    property_query="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### order_by: `str`<a id="order_by-str"></a>

[Order](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) the results by a field.   *  `category` Sorts by project category. A complete list of category IDs is found using [Get all project categories](https://dac-static.atlassian.com).  *  `issueCount` Sorts by the total number of issues in each project.  *  `key` Sorts by project key.  *  `lastIssueUpdatedTime` Sorts by the last issue update time.  *  `name` Sorts by project name.  *  `owner` Sorts by project lead.  *  `archivedDate` EXPERIMENTAL. Sorts by project archived date.  *  `deletedDate` EXPERIMENTAL. Sorts by project deleted date.

##### id: List[`int`]<a id="id-listint"></a>

The project IDs to filter the results by. To include multiple IDs, provide an ampersand-separated list. For example, `id=10000&id=10001`. Up to 50 project IDs can be provided.

##### keys: List[`str`]<a id="keys-liststr"></a>

The project keys to filter the results by. To include multiple keys, provide an ampersand-separated list. For example, `keys=PA&keys=PB`. Up to 50 project keys can be provided.

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

Filter the results using a literal string. Projects with a matching `key` or `name` are returned (case insensitive).

##### type_key: `str`<a id="type_key-str"></a>

Orders results by the [project type](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/GwiiLQ#Jiraapplicationsoverview-Productfeaturesandprojecttypes). This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Valid values are `business`, `service_desk`, and `software`.

##### category_id: `int`<a id="category_id-int"></a>

The ID of the project's category. A complete list of category IDs is found using the [Get all project categories](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) operation.

##### action: `str`<a id="action-str"></a>

Filter results by projects for which the user can:   *  `view` the project, meaning that they have one of the following permissions:           *  *Browse projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project.      *  *Administer projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project.      *  *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).  *  `browse` the project, meaning that they have the *Browse projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project.  *  `edit` the project, meaning that they have one of the following permissions:           *  *Administer projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project.      *  *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).  *  `create` the project, meaning that they have the *Create issues* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for the project in which the issue is created.

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use [expand](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to include additional information in the response. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Expanded options include:   *  `description` Returns the project description.  *  `projectKeys` Returns all project keys associated with a project.  *  `lead` Returns information about the project lead.  *  `issueTypes` Returns all issue types associated with the project.  *  `url` Returns the URL associated with the project.  *  `insight` EXPERIMENTAL. Returns the insight details of total issue count and last issue update time for the project.

##### status: List[`str`]<a id="status-liststr"></a>

EXPERIMENTAL. Filter results by project status:   *  `live` Search live projects.  *  `archived` Search archived projects.  *  `deleted` Search deleted projects, those in the recycle bin.

##### properties: List[`Dict[str, Union[bool, date, datetime, dict, float, int, list, str, None]]`]<a id="properties-listdictstr-unionbool-date-datetime-dict-float-int-list-str-none"></a>

EXPERIMENTAL. A list of project properties to return for the project. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list.

##### property_query: `str`<a id="property_query-str"></a>

EXPERIMENTAL. A query string used to search properties. The query string cannot be specified using a JSON object. For example, to search for the value of `nested` from `{\"something\":{\"nested\":1,\"other\":2}}` use `[thepropertykey].something.nested=1`. Note that the propertyQuery key is enclosed in square brackets to enable searching where the propertyQuery key includes dot (.) or equals (=) characters. Note that `thepropertykey` is only returned when included in `properties`.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`PageBeanProject`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/page_bean_project.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/project/search` `get`

[🔙 **Back to Table of Contents**](#table-of-contents)

### `atlassianjira.projects.update_project_details`<a id="atlassianjiraprojectsupdate_project_details"></a>

Updates the [project details](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/ahLpNw) of a project.

All parameters are optional in the body of the request. Schemes will only be updated if they are included in the request, any omitted schemes will be left unchanged.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg). is only needed when changing the schemes or project key. Otherwise you will only need *Administer Projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg)

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
update_project_details_response = atlassianjira.projects.update_project_details(
    project_id_or_key="10001",
    description="string_example",
    assignee_type="PROJECT_LEAD",
    avatar_id=1,
    category_id=1,
    issue_security_scheme=1,
    key="string_example",
    lead="string_example",
    lead_account_id="string_example",
    name="string_example",
    notification_scheme=1,
    permission_scheme=1,
    url="string_example",
    expand="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### project_id_or_key: `str`<a id="project_id_or_key-str"></a>

The project ID or project key (case sensitive).

##### description: `str`<a id="description-str"></a>

A brief description of the project.

##### assignee_type: `str`<a id="assignee_type-str"></a>

The default assignee when creating issues for this project.

##### avatar_id: `int`<a id="avatar_id-int"></a>

An integer value for the project's avatar.

##### category_id: `int`<a id="category_id-int"></a>

The ID of the project's category. A complete list of category IDs is found using the [Get all project categories](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) operation. To remove the project category from the project, set the value to `-1.`

##### issue_security_scheme: `int`<a id="issue_security_scheme-int"></a>

The ID of the issue security scheme for the project, which enables you to control who can and cannot view issues. Use the [Get issue security schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource to get all issue security scheme IDs.

##### key: `str`<a id="key-str"></a>

Project keys must be unique and start with an uppercase letter followed by one or more uppercase alphanumeric characters. The maximum length is 10 characters.

##### lead: `str`<a id="lead-str"></a>

This parameter is deprecated because of privacy changes. Use `leadAccountId` instead. See the [migration guide](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/deprecation-notice-user-privacy-api-migration-guide/) for details. The user name of the project lead. Cannot be provided with `leadAccountId`.

##### lead_account_id: `str`<a id="lead_account_id-str"></a>

The account ID of the project lead. Cannot be provided with `lead`.

##### name: `str`<a id="name-str"></a>

The name of the project.

##### notification_scheme: `int`<a id="notification_scheme-int"></a>

The ID of the notification scheme for the project. Use the [Get notification schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource to get a list of notification scheme IDs.

##### permission_scheme: `int`<a id="permission_scheme-int"></a>

The ID of the permission scheme for the project. Use the [Get all permission schemes](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) resource to see a list of all permission scheme IDs.

##### url: `str`<a id="url-str"></a>

A link to information about this project, such as project documentation

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use [expand](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to include additional information in the response. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Note that the project description, issue types, and project lead are included in all responses by default. Expand options include:   *  `description` The project description.  *  `issueTypes` The issue types associated with the project.  *  `lead` The project lead.  *  `projectKeys` All project keys associated with the project.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`UpdateProjectDetails`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/update_project_details.py)
The project details to be updated.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`Project`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/project.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/project/{projectIdOrKey}` `put`

)

### `atlassianjira.screens.list_get`<a id="atlassianjirascreenslist_get"></a>

Returns a [paginated](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) list of all screens or those specified by one or more screen IDs.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
list_get_response = atlassianjira.screens.list_get(
    start_at=0,
    max_results=100,
    id=[
        1
    ],
    query_string="",
    scope=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    order_by="name",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### id: List[`int`]<a id="id-listint"></a>

The list of screen IDs. To include multiple IDs, provide an ampersand-separated list. For example, `id=10000&id=10001`.

##### query_string: `str`<a id="query_string-str"></a>

String used to perform a case-insensitive partial match with screen name.

##### scope: List[`str`]<a id="scope-liststr"></a>

The scope filter string. To filter by multiple scope, provide an ampersand-separated list. For example, `scope=GLOBAL&scope=PROJECT`.

##### order_by: `str`<a id="order_by-str"></a>

[Order](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) the results by a field:   *  `id` Sorts by screen ID.  *  `name` Sorts by screen name.

### `atlassianjira.ui_modifications_(apps).create_modification`<a id="atlassianjiraui_modifications_appscreate_modification"></a>

### `atlassianjira.user_search.find_assignable_users`<a id="atlassianjirauser_searchfind_assignable_users"></a>

Returns a list of users who can be assigned issues in one or more projects. The list may be restricted to users whose attributes match a string.

This operation takes the users in the range defined by `startAt` and `maxResults`, up to the thousandth user, and then returns only the users from that range that can be assigned issues in the projects. This means the operation usually returns fewer users than specified in `maxResults`. To get all the users who can be assigned issues in the projects, use [Get all users](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and filter the records in your code.

Privacy controls are applied to the response based on the users' preferences. This could mean, for example, that the user's email address is hidden. See the [Profile visibility overview](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/profile-visibility/) for more details.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** None.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
find_assignable_users_response = atlassianjira.user_search.find_assignable_users(
    project_keys="projectKeys_example",
    query="query",
    username="string_example",
    account_id="string_example",
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### project_keys: `str`<a id="project_keys-str"></a>

A list of project keys (case sensitive). This parameter accepts a comma-separated list.

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

A query string that is matched against user attributes, such as `displayName` and `emailAddress`, to find relevant users. The string can match the prefix of the attribute's value. For example, *query=john* matches a user with a `displayName` of *John Smith* and a user with an `emailAddress` of *johnson@example.com*. Required, unless `accountId` is specified.

##### username: `str`<a id="username-str"></a>

This parameter is no longer available. See the [deprecation notice](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/deprecation-notice-user-privacy-api-migration-guide/) for details.

##### account_id: `str`<a id="account_id-str"></a>

A query string that is matched exactly against user `accountId`. Required, unless `query` is specified.

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`UserSearchFindAssignableUsersResponse`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/user_search_find_assignable_users_response.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/user/assignable/multiProjectSearch` `get`

[🔙 **Back to Table of Contents**](#table-of-contents)

### `atlassianjira.user_search.find_assignable_users_0`<a id="atlassianjirauser_searchfind_assignable_users_0"></a>

Returns a list of users that can be assigned to an issue. Use this operation to find the list of users who can be assigned to:

 *  a new issue, by providing the `projectKeyOrId`.
 *  an updated issue, by providing the `issueKey`.
 *  to an issue during a transition (workflow action), by providing the `issueKey` and the transition id in `actionDescriptorId`. You can obtain the IDs of an issue's valid transitions using the `transitions` option in the `expand` parameter of [Get issue](https://dac-static.atlassian.com).

In all these cases, you can pass an account ID to determine if a user can be assigned to an issue. The user is returned in the response if they can be assigned to the issue or issue transition.

This operation takes the users in the range defined by `startAt` and `maxResults`, up to the thousandth user, and then returns only the users from that range that can be assigned the issue. This means the operation usually returns fewer users than specified in `maxResults`. To get all the users who can be assigned the issue, use [Get all users](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and filter the records in your code.

Privacy controls are applied to the response based on the users' preferences. This could mean, for example, that the user's email address is hidden. See the [Profile visibility overview](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/profile-visibility/) for more details.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Browse users and groups* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg) or *Assign issues* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg)

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
find_assignable_users_0_response = atlassianjira.user_search.find_assignable_users_0(
    query="query",
    session_id="string_example",
    username="string_example",
    account_id="string_example",
    project="string_example",
    issue_key="string_example",
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
    action_descriptor_id=1,
    recommend=False,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

A query string that is matched against user attributes, such as `displayName`, and `emailAddress`, to find relevant users. The string can match the prefix of the attribute's value. For example, *query=john* matches a user with a `displayName` of *John Smith* and a user with an `emailAddress` of *johnson@example.com*. Required, unless `username` or `accountId` is specified.

##### session_id: `str`<a id="session_id-str"></a>

The sessionId of this request. SessionId is the same until the assignee is set.

##### username: `str`<a id="username-str"></a>

This parameter is no longer available. See the [deprecation notice](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/deprecation-notice-user-privacy-api-migration-guide/) for details.

##### account_id: `str`<a id="account_id-str"></a>

A query string that is matched exactly against user `accountId`. Required, unless `query` is specified.

##### project: `str`<a id="project-str"></a>

The project ID or project key (case sensitive). Required, unless `issueKey` is specified.

##### issue_key: `str`<a id="issue_key-str"></a>

The key of the issue. Required, unless `project` is specified.

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return. This operation may return less than the maximum number of items even if more are available. The operation fetches users up to the maximum and then, from the fetched users, returns only the users that can be assigned to the issue.

##### action_descriptor_id: `int`<a id="action_descriptor_id-int"></a>

The ID of the transition.

##### recommend: `bool`<a id="recommend-bool"></a>

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`UserSearchFindAssignableUsers200Response`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/user_search_find_assignable_users200_response.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/user/assignable/search` `get`

### `atlassianjira.user_search.find_users_by_property_and_string`<a id="atlassianjirauser_searchfind_users_by_property_and_string"></a>

Returns a list of active users that match the search string and property.

This operation first applies a filter to match the search string and property, and then takes the filtered users in the range defined by `startAt` and `maxResults`, up to the thousandth user. To get all the users who match the search string and property, use [Get all users](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and filter the records in your code.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

Privacy controls are applied to the response based on the users' preferences. This could mean, for example, that the user's email address is hidden. See the [Profile visibility overview](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/profile-visibility/) for more details.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Browse users and groups* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg). Anonymous calls or calls by users without the required permission return empty search results.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
find_users_by_property_and_string_response = atlassianjira.user_search.find_users_by_property_and_string(
    query="query",
    username="string_example",
    account_id="string_example",
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
    _property="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

A query string that is matched against user attributes ( `displayName`, and `emailAddress`) to find relevant users. The string can match the prefix of the attribute's value. For example, *query=john* matches a user with a `displayName` of *John Smith* and a user with an `emailAddress` of *johnson@example.com*. Required, unless `accountId` or `property` is specified.

##### username: `str`<a id="username-str"></a>

##### account_id: `str`<a id="account_id-str"></a>

A query string that is matched exactly against a user `accountId`. Required, unless `query` or `property` is specified.

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of filtered results (page offset).

The query string cannot be specified using a JSON object. Example: To search for the value of `nested` from `{\"something\":{\"nested\":1,\"other\":2}}` use `thepropertykey.something.nested=1`. Required, unless `accountId` or `query` is specified.

### `atlassianjira.user_search.find_users_by_query`<a id="atlassianjirauser_searchfind_users_by_query"></a>

Finds users with a structured query and returns a [paginated](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) list of user details.

This operation takes the users in the range defined by `startAt` and `maxResults`, up to the thousandth user, and then returns only the users from that range that match the structured query. This means the operation usually returns fewer users than specified in `maxResults`. To get all the users who match the structured query, use [Get all users](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and filter the records in your code.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Browse users and groups* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

The query statements are:

 *  `is assignee of PROJ` Returns the users that are assignees of at least one issue in project *PROJ*.
 *  `is assignee of (PROJ-1, PROJ-2)` Returns users that are assignees on the issues *PROJ-1* or *PROJ-2*.
 *  `is reporter of (PROJ-1, PROJ-2)` Returns users that are reporters on the issues *PROJ-1* or *PROJ-2*.
 *  `is watcher of (PROJ-1, PROJ-2)` Returns users that are watchers on the issues *PROJ-1* or *PROJ-2*.
 *  `is voter of (PROJ-1, PROJ-2)` Returns users that are voters on the issues *PROJ-1* or *PROJ-2*.
 *  `is commenter of (PROJ-1, PROJ-2)` Returns users that have posted a comment on the issues *PROJ-1* or *PROJ-2*.
 *  `is transitioner of (PROJ-1, PROJ-2)` Returns users that have performed a transition on issues *PROJ-1* or *PROJ-2*.
 *  `[propertyKey].entity.property.path is "property value"` Returns users with the entity property value.

The list of issues can be extended as needed, as in *(PROJ-1, PROJ-2, ... PROJ-n)*. Statements can be combined using the `AND` and `OR` operators to form more complex queries. For example:

`is assignee of PROJ AND [propertyKey].entity.property.path is "property value"`

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
find_users_by_query_response = atlassianjira.user_search.find_users_by_query(
    query="query_example",
    start_at=0,
    max_results=100,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

The search query.

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`PageBeanUser`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/page_bean_user.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/user/search/query` `get`

### `atlassianjira.user_search.find_users_for_picker`<a id="atlassianjirauser_searchfind_users_for_picker"></a>

Returns a list of users whose attributes match the query term. The returned object includes the `html` field where the matched query term is highlighted with the HTML strong tag. A list of account IDs can be provided to exclude users from the results.

This operation takes the users in the range defined by `maxResults`, up to the thousandth user, and then returns only the users from that range that match the query term. This means the operation usually returns fewer users than specified in `maxResults`. To get all the users who match the query term, use [Get all users](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and filter the records in your code.

Privacy controls are applied to the response based on the users' preferences. This could mean, for example, that the user's email address is hidden. See the [Profile visibility overview](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/profile-visibility/) for more details.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Browse users and groups* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg). Anonymous calls and calls by users without the required permission return search results for an exact name match only.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
find_users_for_picker_response = atlassianjira.user_search.find_users_for_picker(
    query="query_example",
    max_results=50,
    show_avatar=False,
    exclude=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    exclude_account_ids=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    avatar_size="string_example",
    exclude_connect_users=False,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

A query string that is matched against user attributes, such as `displayName`, and `emailAddress`, to find relevant users. The string can match the prefix of the attribute's value. For example, *query=john* matches a user with a `displayName` of *John Smith* and a user with an `emailAddress` of *johnson@example.com*.

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return. The total number of matched users is returned in `total`.

##### show_avatar: `bool`<a id="show_avatar-bool"></a>

Include the URI to the user's avatar.

##### exclude: List[`str`]<a id="exclude-liststr"></a>

This parameter is no longer available. See the [deprecation notice](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/deprecation-notice-user-privacy-api-migration-guide/) for details.

##### exclude_account_ids: List[`str`]<a id="exclude_account_ids-liststr"></a>

A list of account IDs to exclude from the search results. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Multiple account IDs can also be provided using an ampersand-separated list. For example, `excludeAccountIds=5b10a2844c20165700ede21g,5b10a0effa615349cb016cd8&excludeAccountIds=5b10ac8d82e05b22cc7d4ef5`. Cannot be provided with `exclude`.

##### avatar_size: `str`<a id="avatar_size-str"></a>

##### exclude_connect_users: `bool`<a id="exclude_connect_users-bool"></a>

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`FoundUsers`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/found_users.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/user/picker` `get`

### `atlassianjira.user_search.find_users_with_browse_permission`<a id="atlassianjirauser_searchfind_users_with_browse_permission"></a>

Returns a list of users who fulfill these criteria:

 *  their user attributes match a search string.
 *  they have permission to browse issues.

Use this resource to find users who can browse:

 *  an issue, by providing the `issueKey`.
 *  any issue in a project, by providing the `projectKey`.

This operation takes the users in the range defined by `startAt` and `maxResults`, up to the thousandth user, and then returns only the users from that range that match the search string and have permission to browse issues. This means the operation usually returns fewer users than specified in `maxResults`. To get all the users who match the search string and have permission to browse issues, use [Get all users](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and filter the records in your code.

Privacy controls are applied to the response based on the users' preferences. This could mean, for example, that the user's email address is hidden. See the [Profile visibility overview](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/profile-visibility/) for more details.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Browse users and groups* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg). Anonymous calls and calls by users without the required permission return empty search results.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
find_users_with_browse_permission_response = atlassianjira.user_search.find_users_with_browse_permission(
    query="query",
    username="string_example",
    account_id="string_example",
    issue_key="string_example",
    project_key="string_example",
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

A query string that is matched against user attributes, such as `displayName` and `emailAddress`, to find relevant users. The string can match the prefix of the attribute's value. For example, *query=john* matches a user with a `displayName` of *John Smith* and a user with an `emailAddress` of *johnson@example.com*. Required, unless `accountId` is specified.

##### username: `str`<a id="username-str"></a>

This parameter is no longer available. See the [deprecation notice](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/deprecation-notice-user-privacy-api-migration-guide/) for details.

##### account_id: `str`<a id="account_id-str"></a>

A query string that is matched exactly against user `accountId`. Required, unless `query` is specified.

##### issue_key: `str`<a id="issue_key-str"></a>

The issue key for the issue. Required, unless `projectKey` is specified.

##### project_key: `str`<a id="project_key-str"></a>

The project key for the project (case sensitive). Required, unless `issueKey` is specified.

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`UserSearchFindUsersWithBrowsePermissionResponse`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/user_search_find_users_with_browse_permission_response.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/user/viewissue/search` `get`

### `atlassianjira.user_search.find_users_with_permissions`<a id="atlassianjirauser_searchfind_users_with_permissions"></a>

Returns a list of users who fulfill these criteria:

 *  their user attributes match a search string.
 *  they have a set of permissions for a project or issue.

If no search string is provided, a list of all users with the permissions is returned.

This operation takes the users in the range defined by `startAt` and `maxResults`, up to the thousandth user, and then returns only the users from that range that match the search string and have permission for the project or issue. This means the operation usually returns fewer users than specified in `maxResults`. To get all the users who match the search string and have permission for the project or issue, use [Get all users](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) and filter the records in your code.

Privacy controls are applied to the response based on the users' preferences. This could mean, for example, that the user's email address is hidden. See the [Profile visibility overview](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/profile-visibility/) for more details.

This operation can be accessed anonymously.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:**

 *  *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg), to get users for any project.
 *  *Administer Projects* [project permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/yodKLg) for a project, to get users for that project.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
find_users_with_permissions_response = atlassianjira.user_search.find_users_with_permissions(
    permissions="permissions_example",
    query="query",
    username="string_example",
    account_id="string_example",
    issue_key="string_example",
    project_key="string_example",
    start_at=0,
    max_results=50,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### permissions: `str`<a id="permissions-str"></a>

A comma separated list of permissions. Permissions can be specified as any:   *  permission returned by [Get all permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com).  *  custom project permission added by Connect apps.  *  (deprecated) one of the following:           *  ASSIGNABLE\\_USER      *  ASSIGN\\_ISSUE      *  ATTACHMENT\\_DELETE\\_ALL      *  ATTACHMENT\\_DELETE\\_OWN      *  BROWSE      *  CLOSE\\_ISSUE      *  COMMENT\\_DELETE\\_ALL      *  COMMENT\\_DELETE\\_OWN      *  COMMENT\\_EDIT\\_ALL      *  COMMENT\\_EDIT\\_OWN      *  COMMENT\\_ISSUE      *  CREATE\\_ATTACHMENT      *  CREATE\\_ISSUE      *  DELETE\\_ISSUE      *  EDIT\\_ISSUE      *  LINK\\_ISSUE      *  MANAGE\\_WATCHER\\_LIST      *  MODIFY\\_REPORTER      *  MOVE\\_ISSUE      *  PROJECT\\_ADMIN      *  RESOLVE\\_ISSUE      *  SCHEDULE\\_ISSUE      *  SET\\_ISSUE\\_SECURITY      *  TRANSITION\\_ISSUE      *  VIEW\\_VERSION\\_CONTROL      *  VIEW\\_VOTERS\\_AND\\_WATCHERS      *  VIEW\\_WORKFLOW\\_READONLY      *  WORKLOG\\_DELETE\\_ALL      *  WORKLOG\\_DELETE\\_OWN      *  WORKLOG\\_EDIT\\_ALL      *  WORKLOG\\_EDIT\\_OWN      *  WORK\\_ISSUE

##### query: `str`<a id="query-str"></a>

A query string that is matched against user attributes, such as `displayName` and `emailAddress`, to find relevant users. The string can match the prefix of the attribute's value. For example, *query=john* matches a user with a `displayName` of *John Smith* and a user with an `emailAddress` of *johnson@example.com*. Required, unless `accountId` is specified.

##### username: `str`<a id="username-str"></a>

This parameter is no longer available. See the [deprecation notice](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/deprecation-notice-user-privacy-api-migration-guide/) for details.

##### account_id: `str`<a id="account_id-str"></a>

A query string that is matched exactly against user `accountId`. Required, unless `query` is specified.

##### issue_key: `str`<a id="issue_key-str"></a>

The issue key for the issue.

##### project_key: `str`<a id="project_key-str"></a>

### `atlassianjira.users.get_account_ids_for_users`<a id="atlassianjirausersget_account_ids_for_users"></a>

Returns the account IDs for the users specified in the `key` or `username` parameters. Note that multiple `key` or `username` parameters can be specified.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Permission to access Jira.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_account_ids_for_users_response = atlassianjira.users.get_account_ids_for_users(
    start_at=0,
    max_results=10,
    username=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    key=[
        "string_example"
    ],
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### start_at: `int`<a id="start_at-int"></a>

The index of the first item to return in a page of results (page offset).

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of items to return per page.

##### username: List[`str`]<a id="username-liststr"></a>

Username of a user. To specify multiple users, pass multiple copies of this parameter. For example, `username=fred&username=barney`. Required if `key` isn't provided. Cannot be provided if `key` is present.

##### key: List[`str`]<a id="key-liststr"></a>

Key of a user. To specify multiple users, pass multiple copies of this parameter. For example, `key=fred&key=barney`. Required if `username` isn't provided. Cannot be provided if `username` is present.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`UsersGetAccountIdsForUsersResponse`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/users_get_account_ids_for_users_response.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/user/bulk/migration` `get`

### `atlassianjira.users.get_user`<a id="atlassianjirausersget_user"></a>

Returns a user.

Privacy controls are applied to the response based on the user's preferences. This could mean, for example, that the user's email address is hidden. See the [Profile visibility overview](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/profile-visibility/) for more details.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Browse users and groups* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_user_response = atlassianjira.users.get_user(
    account_id="5b10ac8d82e05b22cc7d4ef5",
    username="string_example",
    key="string_example",
    expand="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### account_id: `str`<a id="account_id-str"></a>

The account ID of the user, which uniquely identifies the user across all Atlassian products. For example, *5b10ac8d82e05b22cc7d4ef5*. Required.

##### username: `str`<a id="username-str"></a>

This parameter is no longer available. See the [deprecation notice](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/deprecation-notice-user-privacy-api-migration-guide) for details.

##### key: `str`<a id="key-str"></a>

This parameter is no longer available. See the [deprecation notice](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/deprecation-notice-user-privacy-api-migration-guide) for details.

##### expand: `str`<a id="expand-str"></a>

Use [expand](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to include additional information about users in the response. This parameter accepts a comma-separated list. Expand options include:   *  `groups` includes all groups and nested groups to which the user belongs.  *  `applicationRoles` includes details of all the applications to which the user has access.

### `atlassianjira.users.set_default_columns`<a id="atlassianjirausersset_default_columns"></a>

Sets the default [issue table columns](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/XYdKLg) for the user. If an account ID is not passed, the calling user's default columns are set. If no column details are sent, then all default columns are removed.

The parameters for this resource are expressed as HTML form data. For example, in curl:

`curl -X PUT -d columns=summary -d columns=description https://your-domain.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/user/columns?accountId=5b10ac8d82e05b22cc7d4ef5'`

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:**

 *  *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg), to set the columns on any user.
 *  Permission to access Jira, to set the calling user's columns.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
set_default_columns_response = atlassianjira.users.set_default_columns(
    columns=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    account_id="5b10ac8d82e05b22cc7d4ef5",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### columns: [`UserColumnRequestBodyColumns`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/user_column_request_body_columns.py)<a id="columns-usercolumnrequestbodycolumnsatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeuser_column_request_body_columnspy"></a>

##### account_id: `str`<a id="account_id-str"></a>

The account ID of the user, which uniquely identifies the user across all Atlassian products. For example, *5b10ac8d82e05b22cc7d4ef5*.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`UserColumnRequestBody`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/user_column_request_body.py)
The ID of a column to set. To set multiple columns, send multiple `columns` parameters.

### `atlassianjira.webhooks.list_failed_webhooks`<a id="atlassianjirawebhookslist_failed_webhooks"></a>

Returns webhooks that have recently failed to be delivered to the requesting app after the maximum number of retries.

After 72 hours the failure may no longer be returned by this operation.

The oldest failure is returned first.

This method uses a cursor-based pagination. To request the next page use the failure time of the last webhook on the list as the `failedAfter` value or use the URL provided in `next`.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Only [Connect apps](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/index/#connect-apps) can use this operation.

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
list_failed_webhooks_response = atlassianjira.webhooks.list_failed_webhooks(
    max_results=1,
    after=1,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### max_results: `int`<a id="max_results-int"></a>

The maximum number of webhooks to return per page. If obeying the maxResults directive would result in records with the same failure time being split across pages, the directive is ignored and all records with the same failure time included on the page.

##### after: `int`<a id="after-int"></a>

The time after which any webhook failure must have occurred for the record to be returned, expressed as milliseconds since the UNIX epoch.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`FailedWebhooks`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/failed_webhooks.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/webhook/failed` `get`

[🔙 **Back to Table of Contents**](#table-of-contents)

### `atlassianjira.webhooks.register_dynamic_webhooks`<a id="atlassianjirawebhooksregister_dynamic_webhooks"></a>

Registers webhooks.

**NOTE:** for non-public OAuth apps, webhooks are delivered only if there is a match between the app owner and the user who registered a dynamic webhook.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** Only [Connect](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/#connect-apps) and [OAuth 2.0](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/oauth-2-3lo-apps) apps can use this operation.

    url="string_example",
    webhooks=[
        {
            "events": [
                "jira:issue_created"
            ],
            "jql_filter": "jql_filter_example",
        }
    ],
)

##### url: `str`<a id="url-str"></a>

The URL that specifies where to send the webhooks. This URL must use the same base URL as the Connect app. Only a single URL per app is allowed to be registered.

##### webhooks: List[`WebhookDetails`]<a id="webhooks-listwebhookdetails"></a>

### `atlassianjira.workflow_scheme_drafts.get_draft_workflow_scheme`<a id="atlassianjiraworkflow_scheme_draftsget_draft_workflow_scheme"></a>

Returns the draft workflow scheme for an active workflow scheme. Draft workflow schemes allow changes to be made to the active workflow schemes: When an active workflow scheme is updated, a draft copy is created. The draft is modified, then the changes in the draft are copied back to the active workflow scheme. See [Configuring workflow schemes](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/tohKLg) for more information.  
Note that:

 *  Only active workflow schemes can have draft workflow schemes.
 *  An active workflow scheme can only have one draft workflow scheme.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
get_draft_workflow_scheme_response = atlassianjira.workflow_scheme_drafts.get_draft_workflow_scheme(
    id=1,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### id: `int`<a id="id-int"></a>

The ID of the active workflow scheme that the draft was created from.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`WorkflowScheme`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/workflow_scheme.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/workflowscheme/{id}/draft` `get`

### `atlassianjira.workflow_scheme_drafts.publish_draft_workflow_scheme`<a id="atlassianjiraworkflow_scheme_draftspublish_draft_workflow_scheme"></a>

Publishes a draft workflow scheme.

Where the draft workflow includes new workflow statuses for an issue type, mappings are provided to update issues with the original workflow status to the new workflow status.

This operation is [asynchronous](https://dac-static.atlassian.com). Follow the `location` link in the response to determine the status of the task and use [Get task](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) to obtain updates.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
atlassianjira.workflow_scheme_drafts.publish_draft_workflow_scheme(
    id=1,
    status_mappings=[
        {
            "issue_type_id": "issue_type_id_example",
            "new_status_id": "new_status_id_example",
            "status_id": "status_id_example",
        }
    ],
    validate_only=False,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### id: `int`<a id="id-int"></a>

The ID of the workflow scheme that the draft belongs to.

##### status_mappings: List[`StatusMapping`]<a id="status_mappings-liststatusmapping"></a>

Mappings of statuses to new statuses for issue types.

##### validate_only: `bool`<a id="validate_only-bool"></a>

Whether the request only performs a validation.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`PublishDraftWorkflowScheme`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/publish_draft_workflow_scheme.py)
Details of the status mappings.

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/workflowscheme/{id}/draft/publish` `post`

### `atlassianjira.workflow_schemes.create_scheme`<a id="atlassianjiraworkflow_schemescreate_scheme"></a>

Creates a workflow scheme.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
create_scheme_response = atlassianjira.workflow_schemes.create_scheme(
    description="string_example",
    default_workflow="string_example",
    draft=True,
    id=1,
    issue_type_mappings={
        "key": "string_example",
    },
    issue_types={
        "key": {
        },
    },
    last_modified="string_example",
    last_modified_user={
        "account_type": "atlassian",
    },
    name="string_example",
    original_default_workflow="string_example",
    original_issue_type_mappings={
        "key": "string_example",
    },
    _self="string_example",
    update_draft_if_needed=True,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### description: `str`<a id="description-str"></a>

The description of the workflow scheme.

##### default_workflow: `str`<a id="default_workflow-str"></a>

The name of the default workflow for the workflow scheme. The default workflow has *All Unassigned Issue Types* assigned to it in Jira. If `defaultWorkflow` is not specified when creating a workflow scheme, it is set to *Jira Workflow (jira)*.

##### draft: `bool`<a id="draft-bool"></a>

Whether the workflow scheme is a draft or not.

##### id: `int`<a id="id-int"></a>

The ID of the workflow scheme.

##### issue_type_mappings: [`WorkflowSchemeIssueTypeMappings`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/workflow_scheme_issue_type_mappings.py)<a id="issue_type_mappings-workflowschemeissuetypemappingsatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeworkflow_scheme_issue_type_mappingspy"></a>

##### issue_types: [`WorkflowSchemeIssueTypes`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/workflow_scheme_issue_types.py)<a id="issue_types-workflowschemeissuetypesatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeworkflow_scheme_issue_typespy"></a>

##### last_modified: `str`<a id="last_modified-str"></a>

The date-time that the draft workflow scheme was last modified. A modification is a change to the issue type-project mappings only. This property does not apply to non-draft workflows.

##### last_modified_user: [`User`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/user.py)<a id="last_modified_user-useratlassian_jira_python_sdktypeuserpy"></a>


The user that last modified the draft workflow scheme. A modification is a change to the issue type-project mappings only. This property does not apply to non-draft workflows.

##### name: `str`<a id="name-str"></a>

The name of the workflow scheme. The name must be unique. The maximum length is 255 characters. Required when creating a workflow scheme.

##### original_default_workflow: `str`<a id="original_default_workflow-str"></a>

For draft workflow schemes, this property is the name of the default workflow for the original workflow scheme. The default workflow has *All Unassigned Issue Types* assigned to it in Jira.

##### original_issue_type_mappings: [`WorkflowSchemeOriginalIssueTypeMappings`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/workflow_scheme_original_issue_type_mappings.py)<a id="original_issue_type_mappings-workflowschemeoriginalissuetypemappingsatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeworkflow_scheme_original_issue_type_mappingspy"></a>

##### _self: `str`<a id="_self-str"></a>

##### update_draft_if_needed: `bool`<a id="update_draft_if_needed-bool"></a>

Whether to create or update a draft workflow scheme when updating an active workflow scheme. An active workflow scheme is a workflow scheme that is used by at least one project. The following examples show how this property works:   *  Update an active workflow scheme with `updateDraftIfNeeded` set to `true`: If a draft workflow scheme exists, it is updated. Otherwise, a draft workflow scheme is created.  *  Update an active workflow scheme with `updateDraftIfNeeded` set to `false`: An error is returned, as active workflow schemes cannot be updated.  *  Update an inactive workflow scheme with `updateDraftIfNeeded` set to `true`: The workflow scheme is updated, as inactive workflow schemes do not require drafts to update.  Defaults to `false`.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`WorkflowScheme`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/workflow_scheme.py)
#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`WorkflowScheme`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/workflow_scheme.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/workflowscheme` `post`

    id=1,

    update_draft_if_needed=False,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### id: `int`<a id="id-int"></a>

The ID of the workflow scheme.

##### issue_type: `str`<a id="issue_type-str"></a>

The ID of the issue type.

##### update_draft_if_needed: `bool`<a id="update_draft_if_needed-bool"></a>

Set to true to create or update the draft of a workflow scheme and update the mapping in the draft, when the workflow scheme cannot be edited. Defaults to `false`.

    id=1,
    workflow_name="workflowName_example",
    default_mapping=True,
    issue_types=[
        "string_example"
    ],
    update_draft_if_needed=True,
    workflow="string_example",
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### id: `int`<a id="id-int"></a>

The ID of the workflow scheme.

##### workflow_name: `str`<a id="workflow_name-str"></a>

The name of the workflow.

##### default_mapping: `bool`<a id="default_mapping-bool"></a>

Whether the workflow is the default workflow for the workflow scheme.

##### issue_types: [`IssueTypesWorkflowMappingIssueTypes`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/issue_types_workflow_mapping_issue_types.py)<a id="issue_types-issuetypesworkflowmappingissuetypesatlassian_jira_python_sdktypeissue_types_workflow_mapping_issue_typespy"></a>

##### update_draft_if_needed: `bool`<a id="update_draft_if_needed-bool"></a>

Whether a draft workflow scheme is created or updated when updating an active workflow scheme. The draft is updated with the new workflow-issue types mapping. Defaults to `false`.

##### workflow: `str`<a id="workflow-str"></a>

### `atlassianjira.workflow_schemes.update_default_workflow`<a id="atlassianjiraworkflow_schemesupdate_default_workflow"></a>

Sets the default workflow for a workflow scheme.

Note that active workflow schemes cannot be edited. If the workflow scheme is active, set `updateDraftIfNeeded` to `true` in the request object and a draft workflow scheme is created or updated with the new default workflow. The draft workflow scheme can be published in Jira.

**[Permissions](https://dac-static.atlassian.com) required:** *Administer Jira* [global permission](https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/x4dKLg).

#### 🛠️ Usage<a id="🛠️-usage"></a>

```python
update_default_workflow_response = atlassianjira.workflow_schemes.update_default_workflow(
    workflow="string_example",
    id=1,
    update_draft_if_needed=True,
)
```

#### ⚙️ Parameters<a id="⚙️-parameters"></a>

##### workflow: `str`<a id="workflow-str"></a>

The name of the workflow to set as the default workflow.

##### id: `int`<a id="id-int"></a>

The ID of the workflow scheme.

##### update_draft_if_needed: `bool`<a id="update_draft_if_needed-bool"></a>

Whether a draft workflow scheme is created or updated when updating an active workflow scheme. The draft is updated with the new default workflow. Defaults to `false`.

#### ⚙️ Request Body<a id="⚙️-request-body"></a>

[`DefaultWorkflow`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/type/default_workflow.py)
The new default workflow.

#### 🔄 Return<a id="🔄-return"></a>

[`WorkflowScheme`](./atlassian_jira_python_sdk/pydantic/workflow_scheme.py)

#### 🌐 Endpoint<a id="🌐-endpoint"></a>

`/rest/api/3/workflowscheme/{id}/default` `put`
